The second are costs for salaries, electricity, petrol, raw materials.
The capital expenses are usually fixed, you need to take them even if the factory is not in use, but they can be written off over time.
Operational expenses are more flexible, like if the factory is standing still it will use very little electricity, but they will also increase when production increases.

The usual model is to own both. You have one or a number of wineyards and you produce your own wine from the varieties you grow making the styles you prefer. This makes for familiarity; your loyal customers will know what to expect.
Some growers just sell their grapes or their jus.
And finally, there are wine makers who just buy grapes from others. Most are large scale producers of mass market wine, but some are small boutique wineries too.
The first way allows you to control the whole process and also to take home the full profit from it. And there will be a reliability in the product.
The second gives you less income, but it will come many years earlier and help your cashflow.
The third gives you the ability to scale according to need, or to experiment.

How do you prepare for a marathon if you don't have any special training?
The same way I did.
1. If you’re overweight (as I was, as a result of working a high-stress corporate job,where I was made to put in 12–18 hour days to keep up with the workload for far too many years, before giving it up and deciding to get back into running again) - the first thing you need to do is go on a Low-Carb (Atkins)/Keto diet, in order to get down to a reasonable weight that won’t put undue stress on your knees, shins, and feet (I went from 305 lbs to 245 lbs, doing low carb/no carb for 6 months) before I started pursuing training to become “marathon ready” for the first time.
 2. There was simply no benefit to carrying around that extra 60 pounds of weight when it comes to any kind of physical training;
 3. It would have unnecessarily increased the chances of injury to muscles, tendons, and joints;
 4. Running would not have reduced that weight had I kept my diet the same (you just don’t burn enough calories while running), while changing my diet decreased the weight far faster than I ever could have done through exercising alone;
 5. By reducing my weight, I also reduced the unnecessary strain on my heart that would have been caused by trying to exercise with an added burden of carrying 60 useless pounds around with me everywhere I went, etc.
 6. So, change your diet up and lost any additional pounds you may be carrying, getting down to a comfortable “starting weight” before you begin any actual physical training. That’s the First Step.
7. Get a good, high-quality pair of Cushioned Running Shoes.
 8. You’re making a commitment to do this right? So, invest in the proper equipment, and get a good pair of highly-cushioned running shoes to prevent any unnecessary shocks to your joints, and prevent injury all the way from your feet up to your knees, to your hips, and to your back
 9. Currently, I’m running in Hoka One One Mach 5’s.
10. If you have been fairly sedentary in the past, without much exercise at all, then you’ll want to start off searching for and locating a (13 week) Walk/Run schedule.
 11. This schedule will take you from alternately jogging for 30 seconds, then walking 4.5 minutes, with this repeating 3 times every other day for the first week; with the distance you “run” progressively increasing little by little each week (e.g. alternately jogging 60 seconds, then walking 4 minutes the second week; etc.), until at the end of 13 weeks you are able to keep your feet off the ground for a full 3 miles non-stop slow run.
 12. 3 Miles is the minimum you need to be able to keep your feet off the ground for before you are ready to start ANY marathon training program.
 13. It is important that you take the time to “condition” your body to this minimum level of running, regardless of how slow or fast it may be, before beginning ANY Marathon Training in order to prevent injury (which means the inability to continue training), as well as to ensure your body is able to recuperate quickly enough between training days to ensure you are able to get good, solid training in on those days you do train once you do begin to undertake any Marathon Training schedule in earnest.
14. Search for and locate a good Marathon Training schedule that starts at the 3 mile conditioning point you have attained.
 15. The one I used was an 18 week program, with 4 training days each week - one “short” run (3 miles)on Monday, one “medium” run (4 miles) on Wednesday, one “short” run (on Friday), and one “long” training run (5 miles) on Saturday.
 16. Each week would have this pattern of - Monday (“short” run), Weds (“medium” run), Friday (“short” run), Saturday (“long” run), with the mileage gradually increasing each week.
 17. The final week of training I believe was Monday (run 14 miles), Weds (Run 16 miles), Friday (run 14 miles), Saturday (run 18 miles).
18. Once you are able to run 18 miles, you are ready to run a marathon. You will have enough strength and endurance built up at that point to make it through the entire 26.2 miles for the very first time.
 19. It should be obvious that you need to time your running schedule so it ends approximately one week before you run your marathon. This one week is to allow for full, complete recovery, and to ensure you have plenty of energy in reserve to go the entire distance.
 20. If you’d like, you can throw in a couple of short “easy” runs in at this time of between 5–10 miles, just to ensure you don’t lose any of that hard-won conditioning you’ve worked so hard to obtain over those prior 18 weeks. One loses approx 10% of their aerobic conditioning for each week one doesn’t run at all. So, a 9 week layoff during the winter, for instance, would mean you’ll have lost 90% of your aerobic capacity (which I’ve done a number of times, living up in the Northwest where bitter cold winters can make it very difficult to keep ones running up during the winter months), when you decide to start into running again.
 21. However, if you do decide to throw a couple of “easy” runs in during those last days before an actual Marathon, you need to be aware that you still need to allow a minimum of 2–3 days dedicated to complete rest prior to the day of the event to ensure complete recuperation, and give yourself your best chance of running your best Marathon possible come the day of the event itself.
 22. It can be hard to resist going out for runs after you’ve become accustomed to going out for nice long runs every couple of days and filling your lungs with all of that nice, clean, fresh air, but you resist you must - absolutely no runs within 2 or 3 days before an actual marathon, with up to a week being considered to be the optimum training/recuperation/rest period before an all-out 26.2 mile marathon.
A Few Additional Insights -
If you lose weight by going on a Ketogenic (less than 5g carbs per day) diet, what you are actually doing is conditioning your system to become a “fat burner” rather than a “sugar (carb) burner”.
What this means is that when you have depleted your body’s stores of glycogen (stored glucose) from the muscles and the liver, your body will already be in condition to switch over to burning fat for fuel.
This because while on a Ketogenic diet, the body upregulates the level of fat mobilization enzymes, decreasing the time it takes to transport the stored fuel (adipose tissue, aka “fat”) from the fat cells through the bloodstream and into the mitochondria of the muscle cells where it is then burned for fuel.
Translated into English, all this realy means is you won’t “bonk”, “hit the wall”, “run out of steam”, “peter out”, etc. once your carb stores (reserves) run out, and instead, your body will automatically switch over to “fat burning mode”, with no sudden decrease in energy felt at all, which would otherwise occur.
There are quite a few videos available on YouTube about Athletes training and performing using the Keto (no carb) diet. The last one I watched was about a Tour de France team taking on the entire race being fueled entirely by a high fat diet, and taking supplementation that contained no carbs at all (primarily using Goose Fat for fuel).
Even though the athletes took in zero carbs, something which until then was not thought possible to do, since it was believed that muscles required glycogen to function, they excelled during the event.
In the recent past, a lot of Athletes, including Professional Football players and those in other sports, as well. have been praising the added endurance and increased performance they gained after becoming “Keto Adapted”, where their bodies began to become conditioned to burn fat for fuel instead of carbs, since fat has a higher energy concentration, lasts longer, and burns more efficiently.
Since here in the US we are all “sugar burners” because of the high-carb diets that are constantly forced upon us by food manufacturers, grocery store offerings, advertisers, and even the misguided and misguiding FDA, it takes a conscious effort to look into and adapt to a Keto diet, which is essentially a Low Carb/No Carb diet… but the results are well worth it (speaking from personal experience).
Even if you only take the time to get yourself “Keto Adapted” (which takes between 2 to 3 months) in order to raise the fat-transport enzyme levels that are needed by your body in order to become a “fat burner”, and then you go ahead and do “carb loading” prior to your event (eating foods high in carbs the day before and the day of the event in order to super-saturate your muscle and liver cells, and raising your glycogen (stored glucose) levels higher than normal) just as Professional Athletes had done before eventually discovering that they could become totally “fat adapted”, this will still go a long way toward preventing you from “hitting the wall” when the glycogen runs out, and will allow your body to switch over to burning stored fat for fuel at the time you most need it to, since you have conditioned your body for this exact situation and eventuality.
So, in a nutshell, that’s how you go from being sedentary and overweight, “without any special training”, to getting yourself in condition to run a marathon… or at least that’s how I did it.
The very first time I took this adventure on, I started dropping weight on a Keto diet in the fall of 2014, by February 2015, I was ready to start the 13 week Walk/Run Training Schedule.
At the end of those 13 weeks, I was running a fairly slow, but steady, 3 miles without taking any breaks, and was recuperating well enough after a good night’s sleep to get up and do all of my normal activities the following day.
It was at that point that I got curious as to what it would take to train for a marathon, as going from an overweight non-runner to an overweight runner hadn’t been very difficult at all. It only took a commitment to stick to the schedule and get out there every day that the schedule said to get out there and put in the time.
Just following the schedule and doing it step by step, it wasn’t hard at all. The schedule made sure I didn’t “overtrain”, and following the schedule made it easy to stay on-track and to keep progressing, gaining more and more endurance each and every time I went out.
When I did the research, I was surprised to find website after website that all said the same thing - if you can keep your feet off the ground for 3 miles, you’re ready to start training for a marathon.
So, having established that, I searched for a “Marathon Training Schedule”, one that only listed the mileage for each week, and didn’t cloudy things up by including what “pace” the distances needed to be run at.
No one new to running knows what a “pace” is, or how to measure it while running, and why these schedules include this unnecessary information that only confuses things and makes it impossible to follow, I have no idea. But I found a schedule that had the weeks and the distances I needed to cover, and it took 18 weeks to go from barely running 3 miles non-stop to running a full 18 miles, and having the energy and endurance to go father (like up to 26.2 miles ;-), if I wanted to.
So, that’s how I did it… and how you can to, if you truly desire to.
It’s a matter of setting your goals. Deciding what point you are at, between your body weight, your current ability to run, and what seems like the best place for you to begin in the process. Then make a commitment to do it, to stick with it, and to get there… and you will.
Your body will adapt and continue getting stronger as you keep progressing, and sticking to the training schedule… and the schedule will make sure you don’t overtrain or injure yourself, and are able to progress steadily and surely, until you’ve attained your goal.
So -
1. Drop whatever weight you need to by changing your diet for a few months until your weight is at a level that doesn’t bother your joints, and can handle the impact of walking farther than you’re currently used to, and where light, easy running (jogging) doesn’t hurt anything.
2. Get a good, high quality pair of highly cushioned running shoes. These can be a bit pricey, but they will more than pay for themselves in saving you from injuries, make you feel like you’re running on clouds, and make the entire process far more enjoyable than you might imagine if you’ve never had a high-quality pair of highly-cushioned running shoes before.
 3. For example, my most recent pair of Hoke One One Mach 5’s cost $139 with free shipping.
 4. I will sometimes purchase the prior year’s model if I particularly liked a shoe from the year before, not only because I love the shoe, but because they usually sell at a reduced price (like $89). Usually after that 2nd year you just can’t get them from anyone anymore as they’re all sold out and the model has been discontinued.
 5. In any case, I cannot emphasize just how important getting a good high quality pair of running shoes is, whether you intend to run on asphalt or run on a treadmill. The shoe will make all the difference in the world to your enjoyment and ability to stay injury free as you set about getting into “marathon condition”.
6. Start with a Walk/Run schedule if you are unable to run 3 miles comfortably to begin with. It doesn’t matter how fast you are able to run at all. the only thing that matters is that you are able to keep your feet off the ground for 3 miles to start training for a marathon. If that’s not the level of conditioning that you’re currently at, then start by searching for and starting off with a Walk/Run schedule.
7. Once you can run 3 miles comfortably, keeping your feet off the ground the entire way, then find and start using a “Marathon Training Schedule”. I recommend finding one that only lists the weeks and the distances you need to cover.
That will do it for you…
As far as Determining Distances -
Once you have your training schedules in hand and are ready to begin training -
I downloaded Google Maps onto my computer. Then, using their “measurement/ruler” feature, I measured out different streets around my area to determine the different routes I could take to meet those distance requirements.
Just measure half the distance you need to run, and then you run there and back for the full distance. So, for a 9 mile run, you just run out to a landmark 4.5 miles away from your starting point, then you run the same 4.5 miles back to where you started, for a total of 9 miles.
Once I’d mapped out all of the various distances, I’d make a notation on the schedule of a couple of landmarks, so I’d know the route I needed to take.
STRETCHING IS ESSENTIAL TO RUNNING
Remember to ALWAYS warm up by stretching before you run (ankles, calves, quads, hamstrings, back).
This is ESSENTIAL.
NEVER run without first warming up by stretching. This will tell your muscles what’s expected of them, the range of motion they are expected to handle, and will prevent injury.
Also, remember to ALWAYS cool down after a run by walking for at least 10 minutes to prevent blood from pooling in your muscles (which has been found to be the #1 cause of heart attacks in older runners, which, coincidentally, always seems to occur after they run without cooling down afterward)…
…and ALWAYS do the same stretches you did during your warm up after your run, as part of your “cool down”, to prevent your muscles from stiffening up, to prevent Delayed Onset Muscle Soreness (DOMS) which is felt the next day or two afterwards, and to help move any pooled blood out of the muscles back into the circulatory system where it can be properly oxygenated and prevent soreness caused by lactic acid buildup, as well as helping to prevent oxygen deprivation should it remain sitting within muscles where it’s no longer needed, and no longer has the muscle contractions it had been using to aid in it’s circulation once you stop running.
So, that’s a pretty good overview for someone who really wants to go from “couch potato” to “marathon ready” in the most pain-free, and quickest, injury-free way of doing it.
There are plenty of “Walk/Run” and “Marathon Training” Schedules available on the web. You just need to do a bit of searching, until you find the ones that make sense to you.
Personally, all I want in a schedule is the training days and the distances. Anything more just makes it confusing and difficult to figure out. No one needs to run “4 miles at a 12 minute pace”, or run “6 miles at a 10 minute pace”. That’s just nonsense unless you have a coach who is going to monitor you and tell you to “slow down” or go “faster” each time you circle a track.
Even for those of us using a Heart Rate Monitor Watch, like a Garmin Forerunner 225, 245, 620 or whatever, keeping track of your pace, constantly staring at your watch is an unnecessary burden, distracts you from your running, and doesn’t do anything to increase the amount of distance you’re going to cover.
All you need to know is how much ground to cover, and what days you need to get out there to cover that ground.
Now, having said that, there is a benefit to having a “Heart Rate Monitor Watch”, which is to ensure that you’re staying within the optimum training zone, the “Aerobic Zone”, keeping your heart rate below the level where you would not be getting enough oxygen to your cells (on my watch it’s the “green zone”, between 112 - 128bpm).
So, a Heart Rate Monitor Watch is nice to have, but not a necessity by any means.
The one thing I’ve noticed as a benefit of finally getting one, after I’d trained without one for about 10 years or so, was that it made me slow down.
When I first started using one, I found that my heart rate was always too high for “optimum training benefit” if I ran however I felt like running. So, I set an alarm to go off so the watch vibrates against my wrist whenever my heart rate went above 128 bpm. By slowing my pace down, and keeping my heart rate within the “green zone”, keeping it within the optimum “aerobic” training range, it was easier to run, easier to run farther, and recuperation was easier simply because I never entered into the “threshold” range where oxygen deprivation begins to occur.
Anyway, this response has already gotten long enough. I think I’ve shared with you everything you need to get started if you’d like to.
It really doesn’t take a lot of effort, honestly. It just takes a commitment, which is just another way of saying “how important is it to you…?”
If you really want to get your body in the best condition it can be in to run a marathon, then you’ll do the things that everyone who wants to get their body in condition to be able to run a marathon does - you’ll take this information, make a plan, make the changes you need to make, and commit to doing it, and making it your reality.
I’ve done a lot of experimenting over the years, experimenting and testing various diets, nutritional supplements, training techniques, running twice a day, HIIT training, etc. and what I’ve laid out above is what I believe to be the shortest, most clear-cut path to becoming “marathon ready” that you can take.
Read it over more than once if you need to, print it out, make notes, do a search for some training schedules that you like and you think will work for you, make a plan, get the equipment you need, and make a commitment. That’s what it takes to take you to your goal.
…and always keep in mind that anything that gets you excited or keeps you excited about achieving your goal is worth whatever it costs to attain it, whether it be a new pair of running shoes every spring before the start of your training season that promises to make your running more enjoyable; a new supplement that you believe will help increase your endurance, performance, and give you faster recovery; or a new Heart Monitor Watch to ensure you don’t over-exert yourself and helps you stay in the optimum “Aerobic Training Zone”.
It’s ALL worth it, if it makes your endeavor more enjoyable, more exciting, and something that you look forward to more than the day before because of it…
All The Best…! ;-)

How can I get a slimmer face?
As you lose weight, the fat will naturally come off from all over your body, including your face.
When you are carrying excessive fat, it is deposited all over your body, including your face, giving your face a “puffy” look. As you shed the excess fat from your body, it will be lost from all over your body, including your face, and your face will have a more “toned”, and “chiseled” look.
Take a look at any series of “before” and “after” pictures of people who have lost significant amounts of weight. One thing you will notice they all have in common is their faces are all “slimmer” after they’ve shed fat from all over their body. It is one of the most noticeable features of those who have lost weight. Their faces always look more attractive and appealing because they no longer look “puffy”, but are firm and proportionate once again after the weight has been dropped.
I dropped 125 lbs, going from 305lbs to 180lbs one year, and at that time everyone mentioned “wow, you’ve lost a lot of weight…!” as my going from a 48″ waist to a 34″ waist was quite noticeable.
However, after I’d regained a bit of weight a couple of years later, I dropped 70lbs to go from 245lbs back down to 175lbs, this time, the loss of weight aound my waist wasn’t as great, going from around 38″ to around 34″, and this time the most common remark I heard was “your face looks so thin…!”.
So, that’s what happens when you shed fat, it comes off from all over your body, including your face.
So, the way to make your face appear thinner (without resorting to “fake” cosmetic “shading” techniques using makeup), is simply to lose weight. As the weight comes off off your body, it will naturally come off of your face, as well.
You’ll look better, you’ll feel better, and others will notice your slimmer face and will comment on it all on their own once it’s noticeable enough.
All the Best…! ;-)

Why does hunger feel good?
The short answer is IT DOESN’T, and IT NEVER HAS.
No one I have ever known has ever thought it felt good to feel hungry…
…especially not those who are chronically hungry.
Feeling hungry means you are starting to think about and to look for food; if that food is not forthcoming, within a short period of time the discomfort of having an unmet need persist continues to grow and turns into a “gnawing” sensation in one’s gut, and eventually turns into pain; pain that the “hungry” individual is willing to do anything to stop, including begging, stealing, robbing, and even willing to murder in order to get the food that will finally give them some relief.
Where did you ever get the idea that it feels “good” to feel hungry…?
That’s just crazy.

Can you recover lost memories through hypnosis? What is the success rate of this method?
The use of hypnosis to retrieve “lost” memories has been proven to be unreliable, as the mind can be led to create “false memories” very easily.
The mind can be led to create images of events that never occurred, to fill in details that seem convincingly real that never were present at all, and to come up with complete imaginings that seem real in every detail and yet that never too place at all in an individuals life, and yet the subject of the experiment can easily be led to believe actually took place when they never did.
This includes convincing a person while their mind is in an entirely open and suggestible state that a person who never existed in their young life did exist; that a fictional character did things to them, or they did things together that never took place at all; that they went to different exotic destinations that they have never been to; that they existed in “past lives” despite their having no knowledge or idea of this before being led down that path of imaginary exploration once the hypnotic and highly suggestible state had been entered into, etc.
This has been written about extensively, and cases of “false memories” induced by hypnosis have been well-documented.
Well-trained hypnotists are taught to avoid going down the path of “past life regression”, or using leading questions when trying to assist subjects who come to them in an effort to retrieve “lost” memories because the mind is known to be so highly suggestible that it will create “memories” of events that never occurred; it will fill in the “gaps” on it’s own with images and details that never existed in reality; and in most courts of law testimony from witnesses who have been “assisted” in “retrieving memories” through the use of hypnosis are no longer accepted because it is recognized that not only are the memories induced in this manner unreliable, but most often are completely false, and nothing more than figments of a persons imagination that were brought about through the use of leading questions while they were in a highly suggestible hypnotic state, and are not to be trusted or relied upon for that very reason - the memories themselves are “induced”, and are not actually “retrieved”.
…they are false imaginings created by that part of the mind that imagines and creates all on it’s own, and will do so when asked to, and most especially when a person is led into being in a very relaxed state, has had all of their conscious mind asked to not compare what they are being told to imagine with anything that actually occurred in reality, and are led on a completely imaginary journey that consists only of what the mind is asked to produce, and is asked to produce these imaginings as convincingly as it is able to. The result being “false memories” that “seem so real” as to convince the subject that these things they have been led to imagine actually happened when time and again known facts have easily proven that they couldn’t have.
There are actually papers that have been written about how to induce “false memories” through the use of hypnosis in oneself.
There are papers that have been written that explain how to use self-hypnosis to induce a very relaxed and highly suggestible state in oneself, and then to let your mind create images of things that you would like to believe have occurred in the past, and to allow your mind to add more and more details to these false images, then through the process of daily repetition to allow these images to then begin to seem “familiar”, and to begin to notice additional details over time that the mind makes up and adds to these images all on it’s own… so that at the end of this process, you can no longer tell that the images that you began knowing had never happened didn’t happen, and that through this process of presenting images and suggestions to the mind, the mind itself begins to lose it’s ability to discern the difference between actual true memories of things that occurred, and what was only merely imagined.
That is the nature of the subconscious mind. It is an image creating machine. It will create images it is asked to create whether they occurred in reality or not.
The mechanism of hypnosis is one of inducing someone to relax physically, mentally, and emotionally, and as one does so, they are induced to go down through the higher brainwave frequencies from gamma, to beta, to alpha (the lightest state of hypnosis), to delta (the deepest state of hypnosis), to theta (deep sleep). As one goes into the slower brainwave states, the conscious mind relaxes, and no longer guards the mind. Once the conscious mind is out of the way, there is no objection to anything the mind is asked to imagine, because objections and all critical thinking comes from the conscious mind.
Once the conscious mind is out of the way, and a hypnosis subject has reached the highly pleasureable Alpha state, where they have no awareness of their physical body, and simply feel as if they are “floating”, they are in a highly suggestible state.
In this highly suggestible state they can be induced to bring up images as desired, and they can be led to believe that the images that they are induced to bring up actually occurred, when they never did. Since the conscious mind is not available to compare these new imaginings they are led to come up with, there is nothing to stop them from being convinced that these completely false images they were asked to come up with actually occurred.
This is further compounded when the hypnotist praises the subject for being such a “good” subject, for having “allowed” these “memories” to come up, and to give them an image of themselves being even more “successful” in “retrieving” more details and more images in “future sessions”, with those things themselves actually being hypnotic suggestions, further entrapping the subject in the illusion of retrieving “lost memories” when they are actually being induced to create “false memories” during these sessions instead…
So, no, using hypnosis for the purpose of retrieving “lost” memories is not very reliable at all, and in fact has been proven to be quite unreliable.
It has been shown that hypnosis is one of the most unreliable methods of retrieving “lost” memories simply because of the nature of hypnosis itself, which is to put someone into a highly suggestible state of mind, to put someone into a state of mind where their conscious mind is not allowed to be active or perform it’s role in preventing false images from being induced, and because this type of “memory retreival” has most often been achieved through the use of leading questions and where the creative nature of the mind has been tasked with creating images of events that are desired by some party and are not actually “retrieved” at all, but have actually been coerced, and “induced” on the part of the hypnotist.
In the course of about 50 years of studying and practicing hypnosis, this was an area that I was very interested in when I was younger. I read quite a number of books on the subject, and over the years saw quite a number of court cases where individuals had been put under hypnosis in an attempt to retrieve “lost” memories.
I was surprised at first by the number of warnings in these books about not using “leading questions” which the mind would take as commands to make up images that had never occurred; how the mind could be convinced that something seemed so real that it had imagined, but which had never occurred; as well as the number of court cases over the years where testimony of someone who had been put under hypnosis and was convinced that what they were induced to imagine had occurred was completely torn apart and where it was proven what they imagined could not have happened.
Beyond the aspect of “memory retrieval”, I also delved into the area of “past life regression”, and also found numerous warnings about not using “leading questions” because the mind was so suggestible, it would easily create images of having lived a previous life all on it’s own, and these images would appear quite realistic, and because it is the nature of the mind to imagine, if a person were successfully put into a hypnotic state, anyone could easily be induced to make up these false images and led to believe they were completely real.
So, those are two areas that I chose never to pursue, but the knowledge, background, and understanding of how the mind is such a highly suggestible, image-creating machine has served me well over the years.
So, no, the use of hypnosis to retrieve “lost” memories is not a “reliable” method to do this at all, and anyone who engages in this type of “memory retrieval” has to have a very good understanding of how the mind works and how to go about such “memory retrieval” in a way that does no lead the subject to create false images as a result of their suggestions, but instead simply allows their anxieties, fears, internal conflicts, etc. to be reduced and to allow the mind, on it’s own, to recall the actual memories of what they are known to have witnessed and experienced, and allow only those slight missing details to surface, which can then be confirmed, and not to have entirely false images of things which have no basis in any known reality to be created and presented as “facts” or as “memories” when they are no such thing…
I am quite surprised in reading over others answers to this and other similar questions regarding this aspect of “memory retrieval under hypnosis” that so few others have pointed any of this known information out.
This aspect of “false memories” being easily induced through hypnosis has long been known, and anyone who actually looks to gain training on “memory retrieval” or “past life regression” through hypnosis from any authoritive and reputable source will find more than ample information regarding how unreliable hypnosis is for this purpose, and why it should not be engaged in by those who are not thoroughly trained and taught how to do it properly because it is so easy for subjects to be misled, and for hypnosis to be misued when used for these purposes.
All the Best..! ;-)

Can someone change their habits without any external help?
Yes, of course they can. It’s been done for thousands of years.
I read that it takes 21 days to form a habit in a book when I was younger (I’ve since learned in reality it takes between 21–42 days, depending on one’s individual neurology). So, I decided to test out this new information for myself and searched for a new habit that I could develop that would be beneficial to me in the future.
Within a day or two it occurred to me that I was not in the habit of picking my dishes up off of the table and putting them in the sink when I was finished eating. This is something that had always been done for me as I was growing up, and even at that time was still being done for me, so I had no need to develop the habit.
However, I realized that I would not always be in such living situations to have others picking up after me, and it would be a habit that I would appreciate as I grew older and was living on my own if I were to develop it. So, that was the first habit that I chose to develop on my own, picking up my dishes and putting them in the sink without thinking about it immediately upon finishing eating.
The first few days it took quite an effort, but I made sure I did it.
Around the end of the first week, I forgot a couple of times, and only realized I hadn’t done it after I’d already walked away from the table and had walked into another room. So, although it took more of an arduous effort than if I had just consciously made myself do it to begin with, I made myself go back and pick up my dishes and put them in the sink.
Even during the second week, I found it took a conscious effort to make myself pick up my dishes and put them in the sink. It was not until sometime during the 3rd week that I began to find that I simply started doing this automatically, without thinking, and it wasn’t until the 4th week that I could say that I had at that point formed a new habit.
By consciously deciding on what would be a new beneficial behavior that I would like to have, and then persistently making myself perform the new behavior through conscious awareness, it simply became easier for my subconscious to automatically start performing the new behavior on it’s own after a few weeks than to have to consciously remember to do it.
After that, I did the same experiment with other things that had never been a habit of mine previously, like making my bed the very first thing when I got out of it in the morning; going out for a run 3 or more times a week regularly; going to the gym 3 times a week; etc.
Anything that you do consciously with persistence over a period of time will soon become a habit, and the amount of time will vary from somewhere between 3 - 6 weeks. Outside influence is not required. Persistent internal desire and motivation is.

How should I start exercising and gradually make it more intense? I never workout and the beginner workouts on YouTube are too much for me.
One method which is very easy to implement is you decide on a set of bodyweight only exercises (calesthenics) that will exercise all of the muscle groups you want to cover, and you get a notebook that you will use for a log to track your progress.
On Day #1, you do one rep of whatever exercises you’ve chosen.
On Day #2, see if you can do two reps of those exercises.
On Day #3 see if you can do three reps of those exercises.
Etc.
On any day you find you cannot do the additional rep, just do what you can, note it in your log, and attempt to add one more rep to that the following day.
Within a week and a half or so you should be up to 10 reps on each exercise you’ve chosen, and up to 10–12 reps for each exercise within 2 weeks or so.
It’s important not to let your strength increase on it’s own in response to the new muscle stimulation you are giving them. All muscles naturally grow stronger to a progressive increase in resistance, and you do not need to offer them massive resistance to stimulate their growth when first starting out. Any resistance will do the trick if you are just starting our after living a sedentary lifestyle.
Although I’ve exercised all of my life, my chest muscles have always been my weakest body part, and one year I finally decided to do something about it. This is the method I used. The first day I did one pushup. The second day I did two pushups. Etc. When I got up in the 20 range there were some days when I did the same number of reps as the day before, because that’s all I could do, but the following day I was able to do one more. By the end of two months, I was able to do 50 pushups at a time whenever I wanted, and to do it easily. I was never sore at any time. Once I was able to do 50 pushups, switching over to doing bench presses using weights and increasing the weights I was able to lift was no problem at all.
So, get a notebook to use as a log to track your progress. That’s an important part of the process. I gives you motivation by giving you something to look forward to, filling that next line in; it gives you satisfaction by letting you see how you steadily progress; and it gives you a sense of accomplishment when you look back over the previous 2 weeks, or a month, or 2 months to see the progress you’ve made and allows you to see how much healthier and stronger you are than when you began.
Then start easy - doing only one rep. That will be enough to stimulate your muscles to grow.
If you feel sore the following day, just do one rep again.
The very beginning part of the process of stimulating muscles to grow is called the “conditioning” phase. It is the time when muscles begin to respond to stimulus that they haven’t received previously, and they start to develop the ability to wash away to lactic acid that forms as a byproduct of their contractions.
As new muscle cells grow, new capillaries need to grow as well to provide them with oxygen, and new nerve cells have to grow so that they can be stimulated to contract when called upon to do so. Muscle cells grow fastest, capillaries grow second fastest, and nerve cells are the last to grow. All three must be in place for new muscle growth to be supported and be maintained.
By utilizing this method, only adding one more rep, as you are able to, each time you exercise, you will find your strength steadily increasing, the demands you are putting on your body easy enough so it doesn’t cause any strain, and is gentle enough to be enjoyable and virtually guarantee that you’ll get to your 1 week, 1 month, or even 2 month goal easily, and you’ll be healthier, stronger, and happy with what you’ve accomplished in the end…
Enjoy…! ;-)

Because there is replacement the 3 events are independent.
This implies that the probability that all 3 occur is exactly the product of the 3 separate probabilities linked with the occurrence of the events.
Each of these 3 probabilities can be found by applying the rule:
Probability = number of favorable outcomes divided by number of possible outcomes.
In each case the number of possible outcomes is clearly 52.
This must be enough for you to find the probability yourself.

Make a picture of the square determined by the points (0,0), (0,A), (A,0) and (A,A).
Draw the line X+Y=B; it divides the square in two parts.
Find an expression for the area of the part that contains (0,0).
Divide this by the area of the square which is A×A.

Number the ten pairs and let A_i denote the set configurations where pair i sits next to eachother.
Then we are aiming to find the number of favorable configurations:
|\bigcup_{i=1}^{10}A_i|
and that can be done by means of the principle of inclusion/exclusion combined with symmetry.
Here:
|\bigcap_{i=1}^kA_i|=2^k(20-k)!
so that:
|\bigcup_{i=1}^{10}A_i| equals:
\sum_{k=1}^{10}(-1)^{k-1}\binom{10}{k}2^k(20-k)!
To get the probability of at least one pair sitting next to eachother divide this by 20! (i.e. the number of possible configurations).

M has geometric distribution with parameter p_1+p_2-p_1×p_2.
Think of two independent sequences of independent trials that can succeed or fail. For the i-th sequence of trials let it be that the trials have probability p_i to succeed.
Then X can recognized as the number of trials needed to arrive at a success for the first sequence and Y likewise for the second sequence.
Note that M also corresponds with such a sequence: there is “success” if there is a success in the first or in the second sequence.
The sketched situations are characteristic for geometrical distribution.

Someone who sticks to his choice will win if his original choice was correct.

Someone who switches will win if his original choice was incorrect.

First some convenient notations:
For positive integer s let [s] be a notation for the set \{1,2,\dots,s\}.
For sets A, B let B^A denote the set of functions with domain A and codomain B.

Let us go for finding the probability that the m random pickings result in exactly r balls that are at least picked once.
We can identify the m random pickings with a randomly chosen element of [N]^{[m]} and to be found is then the probability that the image of this element/function has exactly r elements.
Our first step is finding the number of elements of [N]^{[m]} that have [r] as image. These elements correspond one-to-one with surjections [m]\to[r] and there are r!S(m,r) of them where S(m,r) denotes a Stirling number of the second kind.
Since [N] has \binom{N}{r} subsets that have r elements we can now conclude that the number of favorable outcomes equals:
\binom{N}{r}r!S(m,r)
Every element of [N]^{[m]} is possible so for the probability we find:
N^{-m}\binom{N}{r}r!S(m,r)
You can use this expression for finding the probability that after m picks all balls are picked (just substitute r=N).
Also you can find the probability that after m picks exactly k balls are not picked (substitute r=N-k).

First , all the hydrogen on Earth is chemically tied up in molecules and it is expensive to isolate it.

Third, in the presence of an oxidizer (like air) free hydrogen is virtually explosive. A train wreck which releases hydrogen is like a bomb begging to explode.
Solve these issues, then contemplate the locomotive.

Because the rocket nozzle, the bell shaped end, is a fixed shape and size but to maintain a certain thrust level the nozzle would have to continuously expand the exit area as the rocket ascends, that is as atmospheric pressure lessens. Sauron is one of the Ainur (read: “angels”) created by Eru Iluvatar (read: “God”) before God created the World.
Sauron came to Arda (read: “Earth”) as one of the Maiar (read: “lesser angels”).
So: Sauron’s power is innate. He was created as a supernatural being with the supernatural powers that he possesses. (Note: the One Ring gave him an additional magical ability that he did not naturally possess.)
At the end of The Lord of the Rings, the One Ring was destroyed, and as a result all of Sauron’s constructs - including his own body - crumbled into dust. Sauron was ever after a bodiless spirit, unable to affect or even communicate with anyone in Arda, and unable to form a new material body.

It’s easy to get distracted by social media, work, bills, and survival.
There are so many things that pull our attention away from the important things in life. Those distractions can make us feel like living a good life is outside of our capabilities.
Living a beautiful, stress-free, and peaceful life is possible despite whatever problems you’re facing.
I’m thousands of dollars in debt, I live paycheck to paycheck, I have a job I don’t like, but I’m confident that it’s all okay.
Even if I don’t have all that I want right now, it doesn’t mean that it will never come to me. I know it’s going to happen because I make it possible everyday.
All the long days of work and pushing myself to learn something new everyday will pay off. Everyday that I actively accomplish my goals is a step towards the life of my dreams.
I will make my dreams a reality because I create them everyday.
Here are some things I’ve learned to create a happy life:
1. Live simply - I don’t need much to be happy. Therefore I don’t spend much money on expensive things. I thrift often and almost never buy anything brand new. Social media can pressure us into thinking we need to buy lots of things to live comfortably. But this isn’t true.
2. Live inside of your means — Don’t sacrifice a leg and an arm if you don’t have to. Those means will change the longer you persist in your work. Remember that those means can change with a single choice. Maybe that risky decision can unlock that lifestyle you really want for yourself. Until you make that choice, live inside your means
3. Freedom is a choice — Freedom is doing whatever you want whenever you want. And this is why I work a job I don’t like. Honestly, I don’t like working at all. I don’t like doing things I don’t find interesting, engaging, or worth my time. To reach freedom, I will choose to learn skills that can unlock freedom.
Here are my three things that I think are worth learning. I hope this helps.

Be honest with yourself.

Be honest about what you want, why you want it and who you want it with.
Tell me what you truly want to be.
Tell me what you really want to spend your time doing.
Tell me what you want most out of life.
Tell me how you want to live your life.
Tell me about who your life includes and who it doesn’t.
Do all of these things and just be honest about everything.
I spent my early 20’s wanting so much and yet, I hide it from the people I loved the most. I hid the truth from my family and friends because I was afraid of being seen in a negative way.
I cared too much about the opinions of others.
I cared so much that I built a house of cards and tried to build my life on top of it. Overtime this structure got weaker and weaker. It got this way because I lied…a lot.
I lied about what I liked and didn’t like.
I lied about what I truly thought.
I lied about how I truly felt.
I lied about what I wanted to do.
I lied so much that I forgot that I didn’t have to lie at all.
I fed myself so many lies that I lived in them and they became a part of me. I’m at a point where I’m learning to get comfortable with saying my truth.
I’m learning to not hide my truth even if it’s something others will hate, disagree with, or dislike.
I’m learning how to be honest with myself so that I can create an honest life. I believe this can lead me to a greater peace.
I hope this one thing, can drastically change your life, like it’s doing for me. I hope you find this and so this as soon as possible.
Don’t make the same mistake I made. Don’t lie about who you want to be, what you want to be, where you want to do it, or who you want to be with.
Live honestly and you will find the ultimate happiness in life.

Here’s my best parenting advice:

(1) Pay attention to your kids.
I’m not talking about speaking to them at breakfast or dinner, or only when you have the time. I mean like really pay attention to your kids. Let them know you’re there for them, like really there.
Be there to listen, to understand, to teach, to accept, and to forgive them. I know what it likes ti live in a home with more than five family members and truly not know any of them.
(2) Your kids will live life how you see it.
Kids are copycats. They do everything WE do, they are little mirrors reflecting expressions, emotions, and behaviors that we share. Everything you do as a parent is being watched and learned.
Pick your actions wisely, because your kids will surely follow.
(3) Choose your words wisely.
I remember everything my parents ever did in front of me. I remember the fights before the divorce. I remember the screaming, yelling, and crying. I remember some of the most hurtful things my parents have ever said to me.
Words have power. They can alter the way you see yourself and perceive reality. Choose them wisely because kids hear EVERYTHING.

I hope this helps, happy Saturday loves ☮️

Your supposed to keep going despite your failures.

This year, I managed to ruin my relationship with myself, my husband, and my family. I fucked up so bad that I managed to hurt everyone around me.
It’s because of those mistakes that I dug myself inti a dark pit. For the past months, I’ve been living in the past, suffering in the memory of my past.
It’s been the hardest thing, I’ve ever had to overcome. Truthfully, there are days when I stumble and sit in my feelings.
The thing is that dwelling in those feelings do nothing for you. Living in the past doesn’t help you grow. Telling yourself you’re a fuck up, doesn’t help you get to the place where you want to be.
Pain is inevitable but suffering is a choice. All of us aren’t perfect, we all stumble, fail, and make countless mistakes. But those mistakes shouldn’t stop us from moving on in our lives.
When you keep getting worse, it means you’re going through the motions. It’s always going to get worse before it gets better. Sometimes that tough period is what we need in order to grow.
Maybe that negative experience can contain something good. Maybe it’s an opportunity to flip the switch and become a stronger individual.
When it seems like everything is falling apart, no matter what, keep on going. I believe in you.

It is possible if you can let go.

For me personally, this has been my year of fuck ups. I messed up and made so many mistakes that they exploded in my face all at once.
This year it felt like I couldn’t catch a break. I feel like I messed up so bad that nothing can be what it was.
I made huge mistakes with myself, my family, and my relationship that sometimes I become overwhelmed with intense sadness.
Admittedly, I spent this entire year obsessing over these mistakes and all they’ve done is stir my mind and my emotions in the wrong direction.
I know what its like to feel so guilty and ashamed that it feels like you deserve the punishment. Like you deserve suffering and more for all that you’ve done.
It’s a pain I wouldn’t wish upon my worst enemy, and truthfully, it’s something that I’m trying to heal from still.
Some days are good and others and hard. But I think moving on is possible if we grant ourselves the blessing of forgiveness.
We aren’t perfect beings and it’s guaranteed that we are bound to fail. As hard as it sounds, we must find a way to understand our mistakes, accept that they happened, and acknowledge that we are worthy of forgiveness.
If we can manage to do all of these things I think it’s possible to live in peace.

Here, z = {(a^20) + (a^10) + 1}
Let, (a^10) → x mod 31
Then, z → (x^2 + x + 1) mod 31
Now, we are to look for positive integers from 1 to 30 for which (x^2 + x + 1) mod 31 → 0 mod 31. And we find just two ……….. x = 5 and x = 25:
(5^2 + 5 + 1) = 31 → 0 mod 31
(25^2 + 25 + 1) = 651 → 0 mod 31
Now, (31 - 1) / 2 = 15 ……………… just by brute force check for positive integers from 1 to 15 to find whose 10th power fits into (5 mod 31) or (25 mod 31) shape.
On checking we find for 5, 9, 10, 11 and 13 ………… each of their 10th power gives (5 mod 31).
Also we find for 3, 6, 7, 12 and 14 …………. each of their 10th power gives (25 mod 31).
And for 1, 2, 4, 8 and 15 ………….. their 10th power neither gives (5 mod 31) nor (25 mod 31).
Therefore, any positive integer that fits into (31w ± 3), (31w ± 5), (31w ± 6), (31w ± 7), (31w ± 9), (31w ± 10), (31w ± 11), (31w ± 12), (31w ± 13) and (31w ± 14) will do for a.

If you observe minutely you will find the beginning days of the 12 months of any common year, containing 365 days, can be classified as per following:
I) January & October having the same day of the week as their beginning days.
II) February, March & November having the same day of the week as their beginning days.
III) April & July having the same day of the week as their beginning days.
IV) September & December having the same day of the week as their beginning days.
V) The beginning day of May of the week is not similar to any other month of the year.
VI) The beginning day of June of the week is not similar to any other month of the year.
VII) The beginning day of August of the week is not similar to any other month of the year.

When dot product of two vectors is taken, it multiplies any one of these two vectors by the component of the other along its direction.
When there are two vectors a and b; the dot product will be:
(a . b) = (magnitude of a) * (magnitude of the component of b along a) = (magnitude of b) * (magnitude of the component of a along b).
Let θ be the angle between the vectors a and b.
Then, (a . b) = |a| * |b| * cos θ.
In this case, |a| = 2, |b| = 8 and θ = 90°.
Then, (a . b) = 2 * 8 * cos 90° = 2 * 8 * 0 = 0.

Let the vector be (ai + bj + ck).
The vector lies in xy-plane; so it must be c = 0.
Therefore, the vector becomes (ai + bj).
The vector makes 30° angle with y-axis ……… so the vector makes (90° - 30°) = 60° angle with x-axis.
So, tan 60° = √3 = (b / a)
Now, y-component of this vector = b = (2√3)
So, a = 2.
The vector = {2i + (2√3)j}.
So, magnitude of x-component of the vector = 2 units.

TOYOTA is a six-letter word.
There are three consonants in it: T, T and Y.
There are three vowels in it: A, O and O.
There are three even positions and three odd positions in any six-letter word.
The three above consonants can be accommodated in three even positions in [(3!) / {(2!) * (1!)}] = 3 ways.
And for every arrangement of the consonants, the three above vowels can be accommodated in three odd positions in [(3!) / {(2!) * (1!)}] = 3 ways.
The answer will be in (3 * 3) = 9 ways.

Believing that every question has only one option as its correct answer.
Probability of answering a question correctly = (1 / 4) = 0.25.
Probability of answering a question wrongly = (1 - 0.25) = 0.75.
There are 10 questions.
So, the probability of getting a zero = probability of answering all 10 questions wrongly = (0.75^10) = 0.05631351470 ≈ 0.0563.

Thanx for the A2A Mathew. I record a lot of my drum tracks using an e-kit. If you are recording using a computer/DAW setup the beat and easiest way is to connect the kit to your computer directoy and use it as a MIDI trigger. You will need a Virtual Instrument plugin such as Toontrack’s EZ Drummer or Superior Drummer (for even more control over all aspects). There are quite a few different drum VI options out there today and moat of them are awesome. I use Superior Drummer most of the time, but also have EZ Drummer, Tony Coleman Drums, Steven Slate Drums, Addictive Drums & Melda’s MDrummer. All have their Pros and Cons. Lets go with EZ Drummer for Shits & Giggles though. The drum plugin will in essence take the place of your kits brain. It will allow you to pick the kit you want to use for the actual drum sounds, and trust me, they are outstanding. Most kita will map to the drum triggers automatically, but you can manual assign them if need be fairly easily. Connect your kit to your computer directly, NOT thru your interface. Make sure it’s available as a MIDI device. Now in your DAW (I use Pro Tools most of the time) you create a new Instrument track, select EZ as the plugin and your e-kit as the trigger. Within the plugin you select the kit you want, the included kit is excellent, but there are almost an unlimited amount & genre of expansion kits available as an add on Toontrack. Now you just go about recording as you normally would. The kit will trigger the drum samples the same as of you were playing through your amp w/the kits module (brain). You monitor via headphones FROM THE INTERFACE, not the headphone out on the module and I HIGHLY recommend unplugging the amp. It would be confusing due to any latency that might occur. I do recommend Toontrack’s EZ Drummer as a starting point if you are not familiar with drum software/VI’s. As the name states it’s EZ to grasp and use, but don’t let that bame fool you into thinking it’s simplistic or sounds horrible. Far from it, the individual drum and cymbal sounds were sampled from real drums. They are NOT computer generated crap. The software also has many additional features that are VERY useful. It offers preset beats, fills, intros & outros. You can piece together complete songs using this feature and never have to hit a drum. Superior Drummer is even more powerful and it’s features are amazing. The mixer section alone is a powerful feature. You can fine tune every aspect of your kit/sounds. You can add plugins ie compression, on each individual piece, pan left or right. Every piece of your kit’s virtual mic has it’s own channel. For instance, top & bottom of the snare are two separate channels, each controllable individually. You can even do up to 16 channel out recording if you want. You can micromanage to your hearts content lol.
If you were unaware this was possible, go enjoy a whole new world of drum recording w/o the multitude of mic, space, tone and loudness issues.

A Pro would get the levels dialed in on the fly in short order, EQ might take some time, which will be tougher with everything, including crowd noise & the sound difference their bodies add to the venue going on. Every instrument would be a distraction frequency wise. Biggest issue would be monitor mixes changing while he/she is working the board. Stage volume isn’t like it used to be. Some musicians go direct and those speaker cabs you see on stage are more window dressing. The artists will have to deal with it, use their skill and take what they get till it gets sorted. Truth is, a traditional sound check is a choreographed act. Most big acts, if not all travel with their own PA & sound team and just about all are digitally controlled today. They already have “scenes” for everything and presets they can just punch in with the click of a mouse. This would put the sound either right where it needs to be or just needing a little tweaking. That of course will be saved as a new preset. Monitor mixes are also already setup in the digital age too. In the old days of floor monitors, they generally had a mix of everything (sans vocals in some setups due to feedback issues) blaring out. Now days you can pick and choose exactly what you want and don’t want to hear in your IEM’s. For example, the bass player may want just the drums and a click track in his mix. The guitar player might want the drums & other guitar and a click and so on. So in todays age and back in the day, any sound guy worth their paycheck will have it dialed in fairly quickly.

Thanx for the A2A Kavishwara. All three microphones you ask about are excellent choices to have. The first two are dynamics, the Röde NT-1(a) is a LDC or Large Condenser Diaphragm. The NT-1 will be the most sensitive of the three and would be my last choice for an untreated room. But there are ways you could use it if you feel it gives the best vocal tone you are trying to achieve. The SM58 is one of the most well known mics when it comes to live performance, but it works just as well in the studio. Being a Cardioid pattern mic, it affords you excellent side rejection so it would be a good choice. The SM7b is known to require a little extra gain in the basic home studio setup. Meaning without external Preamps or processing in the tracking chain, straight through your interfaces built-in Pre’s. Not all, but in a good chunk of those on the market today for sure. Using an inline booster like a CloudLifter solves this issue in 99.999% of cases, but it’s not always a must. That said, the SM7b would be my first choice in an untreated room and I would set it to a Flat response. But why not test all three and go with the one that gives you what you are looking for ? Now for the condensor mic, the NT-1, I would suggest using some blankets in front of, and on the sides if possible to help kill any unwanted noise and reflections. Moving blankets are cheap and work great. A closet full of clothes can work in a pinch too.

I’ve been changing my own oil since I bought my first car, a 1970 Chevy Chevelle when I just turned 17yrs old. And I still do. I also do my kids cars and a couple close friends if asked too. There’e a multitude of reasons. Number one being, if I do it myself I know it actually got a new filter & fresh oil. There are unscrupulous shops that will simply clean off your old filter and mark it with a date as if they just changed it. The next time you bring your car in you will actually get a new filter. I’ve seen it done and caught 3 different shops doing this. Two of them being very well know chain franchises. Second, I know exactly what brand of oil is being pit in my vehicles. While most shops buy in bulk (55gal drums) and brands like Mobile One etc, some will refill those barrels with cheaper generic oil of the same weight. I’m not going to name any shop in particular of doing this, but I know it’s been done as I’ve been told by employees who were friends. Third, I know the drain plug has been reinstalled and when needed, changed out for a brand new one. Forth, I won’t risk the shop doing anything to my car in an attempt to upcharge me. For example, tearing the rubber on a windshield wiper or throwing dirt/dust in the air or cabin filters. Or worse as a friend of mine experienced from a Goodyear shop where they punched a small hole in his radiator and said, he “might need one soon”. My Step daughter called me once from a local oil change shop and asked me if she should let the guy change her cabin air filter at a cost of $85usd. After I stopped laughing and told her she should have asked me to do the oil change, tell them yo pound sand. I got it and changed it for her the next day at a cost of $9usd. As for it being cheaper, see all of the above as to exactly why. The savings is not that big anyway, and i like to use Royal Purple in my Challenger which shops don’t stock and if they did, the cost to me from them would be ridiculous. Fact of the matter is, it only takes about 20mins to do, even faster when you know your vehicle and you have the proper jack, stands and tools. Get you hands dirty, it’ll do you good !

Thanx to all who asked me for an A2A on this one. You ask: If one had a Stratocaster, would one still need a Tele?
I got a good chuckle out of this question. Why you ask ? Because guitar players always need another guitar lol. Well, need is most likely the wrong word they would use. Fact is one can never have enough guitars or options tonally right ? I kid of course. But seriously, the Tele is kind of unique. It can be used for just about any genre, even extreme metal if need be. Would I reach for my Tele to play metal ? No, I would grab one of my Humbucker loaded guitars, moat likely one of my Les Paul’s. But don’t discount the Tele due to it’s Single coil setup, besides, the Tele is available with Humbuckers too. The Strat is also an extremely versatile axe. It can provide many different tonal possibilities. It isn’t pigeon holed into any certain genre either. Now, both do have certain ones they excel at. Playing blues on a Strat is hard to beat. Bends sound very soulful, especially on a maple fretboard Strat IMO. The Tele has the same ability with a different tonal palette. And it’s tough to beat the sound and vibe of a Tele played with through an extremely clean tube amp. That glassy tone is pure heaven IMO. And I’m a Les Paul guy BTW. So I believe if you can afford it, and you find one that feels “right”, yes…one needs it. The Tele is to Fenders what the SG is to Gibson. Both have a distinct tone that you can pick out upon hearing. Well at least I can usually tell. Especially the SG and when played with some gain. Not full blown Metal gain. Just a little Classic Rock grit.

The next step after AI is AI creating AI; therefore, creating an exponential expansion of self replicating machines. If humanity can control AI from competing with humans, the world will just need minimal human interaction to co-exist with AI. AI will maintain all the productivity of the planet, and R&D. Humans will continue to contribute imagination.

Yes, intelligence is mental acuity. IQ is a measure of this attribute. But intelligence does not mean knowledgeable. IQ measures the ability to acquire knowledge and organize it efficiently and quickly. But, knowing, understanding and experiences still have to be learned, regardless of natural intelligence.

The answer is “MORE AI.” AI isn’t a fixed or static commodity or software. It’s an exponential expansion. It builds on itself, each step is a faster replication of the previous step…expanding as it goes. The only limitation is the source of data from which AI builds. But AI gains from this also. AI can contribute to this data base too; hence, gaining speed and ability from its own data. This is a “self-fulfilling-prophecy” on steroids. The only things stopping AI are the laws of physics (& AI may even rewrite physics).

What? Don’t you think progress is important? This progression is the way society has always improved. It’s always easy to think the “good old days” were better. But, without progress we wouldn’t have a lot of the things we value today.

You need to work this by subject, not by number of books. You need to select a topic that is of interest to you and read everything you can get your hands on about it until you’re an expert.
The term genius isn’t apt here. You can’t be a genius unless you have an IQ in the range of 135 to 140, or higher. Reading books doesn’t give you a higher IQ. But it does give you more knowledge, which is important regardless of what your IQ is.
You can appear smarter by being knowledgeable and learned. in order to answer your question, you would have to become a knowledge generalist. You’d have to pick multiple subjects in which to become an expert. So, to adequately answer your question you have to read hundreds to thousands of books to accomplish what you’re describing.
You need to become an expert in one subject at a time. If you do that, and you’ll accomplish what you wanted.

You can increase your knowledge and aspects of IQ…but reading won’t really increase your intelligence by much. IQ mainly comes from the way your brain is ‘wired’ at birth. There are some environmental experiences and hand-eye exercises that can increase IQ by 10–15%; but, they aren’t by reading a lot.
However, knowledge needs to be acquired. Knowing more is a tremendous asset. By reading a lot you certainly can appear to be more intelligent by just knowing more…
Go for it…

I saw one answer regarding a “tidal lock”, and a couple more suggesting two suns. The first implies slow changes over an extreme ammount of time, and the second implies preexisting conditions.
I think these answers miss the context of the question: what would happen if the sun stopped setting?
To me this implies that the sun rose one day, and just didn’t set! (Note that my answer can also be applied to an incident in the bible where the sun stopped its movement in the sky!)
This would be very bad for just about every living thing on the planet. Depending on the speed of this rotational braking we get worse, or SLIGHTLY better, outcomes. I don’t have the math skills to give you anything but the worst case scenario.
So, the sun rises, but it doesn’t set. This implies an observer sees it rise but not set. This observer can observe a span of sky approximately 180° wide. With the earth having a circumference at the equator of about 26,000 miles and completing one rotation in 24 hours, this gives it a rotational speed of just over a thousand miles an hour!
That’s a lot of energy, and everything on the surface of the planet has that same velocity. So when the earth suddenly stops rotating EVERYTHING on the planet just keeps moving along at 1,000+ (this will diminish as you move into higher latitudes, but that is not within my scope!), until friction slows it down.
The Pacific ocean will wash over the western United States at 1,000 miles an hour (the same would apply to the western shore of EVERY land mass on the planet!) likely overtopping the Cascade mountains, not sure if it would reach or stop at the Rocky mountains. I invite others to comment on that.
As to other objects on the planet: ships at sea; buildings; trains; planes, and autombiles (yes, and people, too), you can see that they would be very disturbed at finding themselves bouncing across the landscape at 1,000 miles an hour! A very bad day for all!
As i said, I invite others to work out the mathematics on slower rates of rotational braking while keeping the observed position of the sun within the original 180° limits.
Hope this makes your day!
Just sayin’.

It is not very likely that social security will be cut across the board by 20% in the next decade.
What is more likely to occur is what they have already done in the past. Which is to make incremental changes and make the age at which a social security recipient receives full benefits increase.
Here is a good example of what I am talking about.
The current full age of retirement for social security is based on what year you were born. If you were born before 1955 your full age of retirement is 65.
If you were born between 1955–60 your full age of retirement is between 65–67. If you are born in 1960 or later your full age of retirement is 67.
But, there is another way social security recipients see a reduction of 30% in their monthly benefits. That happens if you retire early at age 62.
And the most common age to retire at in the U.S. is 62. Approximately 18% of retirees retire at age 62.
So, the most likely scenario is that the government will continue gradually increasing the full age of retirement and possibly encouraging more people to retire at age 62 where they can give them a whopping 30% reduction in benefits.
It’s feasible we might see a push to make the full age of retirement 68 to 70. Another way to cut costs is to increase early retirement to 63 with the same consequences of a 30% reduction.

As it happens, my desk is situated so I’m facing about twenty degrees west of south. So, I would say, “That’s south” and point them twenty degrees east of where I’m facing now. Being an amateur geographer, astronomer, photographer and photo curator in Wikipedia, I am usually oriented, even when indoors, and often when it’s a landscape painting a few centuries old.

This is why I hate people. Living people, that is, whom someone has decided is worthy.
We don’t do worthy in deciding whether a Wikipedia biography ought to exist. It isn’t a question that we spend much time on. Maybe we should, but more likely it would increase rather than decrease the nuisance of biographies. Instead we do “notability” which means they are subjects of reliable and independent sources.
I, for example, have been the subject of profiles in NY1 TV News and in the Queens Daily Eagle. Perhaps I am also worthy, but what saves me from the horrors of Wikipedia biography is that those news stories in reliable sources are not independent. They are based on interviews with me and have almost no information that I didn’t give them. Interviews are basically autobiographical; I cannot be a reliable source on myself.
Mind you, years ago when I instigated a biography of a living person, her worthiness entered into my own decision. However, rather than write the article I checked to see whether she was mentioned anywhere in Wikipedia. She wasn’t, so I mentioned her in the long-existing Wikipedia article about her most famous project; other editors made the decision to seek out reliable sources and write the biography. It doesn’t mention some of the most interesting things about her, but I don’t have that information from reliable sources, that is to say fitting the strict Wikipedia rules of reliability, so her Wikibiography doesn’t mention those topics.
If you think someone is “worthy” and there are good sources for something important that she has done, you can mention her in the article about that important thing. Of course this may not work for someone who isn’t important to any important event or subject, but in that case what does “worthy” mean? I am acquainted with many people I think worthy, but I wouldn’t inflict biography on them unless they did something equally nasty to me.
Come to think of it, an acquaintance died two years ago, an elderly and worthy fellow Wikipedia editor. He might barely qualify for a Wikipedia biography, but we didn’t think of doing that to our friend. Rather, we collaborated on an obituary in the internal Wikipedia newspaper. I am similarly elderly and hope for similar treatment when I kick off.

Only a little more than two hundred languages have their own Wikipedia. A few others, including Klingon, are not officially Wikipedias; they are something in Wikia. To make a real Wikipedia for a language that doesn’t have one, you need a bunch of editors ready to write it. Many of the smallest ones are very poor and a few of the large ones are even poorer because the majority of articles are written by robots.
As for the best, that’s hard to decide. English is clearly the largest. The question of “best” is sometimes discussed when we have international meetings such as the one we will have in Cracow, Poland next August. Many think the bigger ones (apart from the bot-written ones) tend to be better than the smaller ones, with exceptions and quibbles over what “best” ought to mean.

Yes, a couple years ago I used Google’s AI writer to write part of a Wikipedia article. Decades ago I worked as a telephone technician and learned about:

Now as a retired tech I’m a full-time Wikkian and wanted to improve this article but I didn’t know enough about the topic from a power-line perspective, which since my day has become by far the most important use of this method. However, the corresponding German article was bigger and apparently better, though I can’t actually read German.
So, I had Google translate it, and selected the parts that I wanted to put in the English article. I am familiar enough with the technology to check the translated prose for technical accuracy, and I also checked to see that the citations were still alive. Some of the word choices were off; for example the Google translator used “twist” in several places where “transpose” is better in English, and I had to de-Germanize some of the syntax. Some of the prose was so confused that I couldn’t understand it and simply omitted those parts, patching the gaps with a smaller and less informative summary in my own words. The most confusing part was about an obsolete German system that was completely unfamiliar to me; I omitted all of that rather than wrestle with it.
I think the effort was worthwhile, but I don’t intend to make a regular practice of it until AI translations become less dependent on thorough review. Several of my Wikipedia colleagues who do a lot of multilingual work are somewhat more eager to use AI translators. All the ones I work with were careful to warn me that these programs can only produce a very rough draft that needs careful checking and correction before it is released into the wild. The result is not so much a machine translation, as a machine-assisted translation. If machine translations ever become good enough not to need intensive human supervision, they will also become unnecessary for Wikipedia, since a reader will invoke a translation without our help.

The most common guidance methods for weapons are satellite radio navigation and laser pointers. When GPS or other radio nav doesn’t work, for example because the radio signals are jammed, usually guidance is by a laser shining a coded light beam on the target. Sometimes someone on the ground points the laser. Sometimes the laser is in the air, in a manned or unmanned vehicle. The light beam, however, can be stopped by clouds.
When both radio navigation signals and light signals are foiled, guidance works more poorly. Then it’s most commonly inertial guidance or TV guidance using remote control radio signals that are not jammed when radio nav is, or passive homing as used by infrared anti-radar missiles.

You appear to be right that iPhone speech recognition is limited to one minute at a time. I can't say I know what the reason is. But I will suggest this: If you actually need to dictate for more than one minute at a time, install the Microsoft SwiftKey keyboard. It's a superior speech recognition system, and it isn't limited to one minute of dictation. You can pause your dictation without being cut off. It will punctuate and capitalize for you automatically. One shortcoming I have found is that you need to speak continuously or it will insert a period and start a new sentence where you don't want one. Think about what you're going to dictate before speaking.
To illustrate how good it is, here is an excerpt I just read about aloud from Mark Lawrence's book “The Book That Wouldn't Burn.” It took me well over a minute to dictate. I haven't corrected any errors in it.
