Carbon dioxide (CO2) doesn’t directly heat the Earth, but but it contributes to the retention of heat by the Earth’s atmosphere through a process called the greenhouse effect. The greenhouse effect is a natural process that helps to keep Earth's temperature warm enough to support life. Greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide, absorb infrared radiation and then re-emit it in all directions. This process traps heat in the atmosphere, which warms the planet.
However, human activities, such as the burning of fossil fuels, are increasing the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere, which is causing the greenhouse effect to become stronger.
Here is how CO2 heats the Earth:
1. Sunlight passes through the Earth's atmosphere and warms the Earth's surface.
2. The Earth's surface then emits infrared radiation (heat) back into the atmosphere.
3. Some of the infrared radiation is absorbed by greenhouse gases, including CO2.
4. The greenhouse gases then re-emit the infrared radiation in all directions, including back towards Earth's surface.
5. This process of absorption and re-emission of infrared radiation traps heat in the atmosphere, which warms the planet.
CO2 is a particularly effective greenhouse gas because it absorbs infrared radiation at a wide range of wavelengths. This means that a lot of the infrared radiation emitted by the Earth's surface is trapped by CO2 in the atmosphere.
The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased by about 40% since the Industrial Revolution. This increase in CO2 is the primary cause of global warming, which is the long-term increase in the average global temperature.

Mormons have been confused about the Word of Wisdom since it was first declared. First, it was explicitly not a commandment. Then a later church president said, forget that, now it is a commandment, and members who don't obey it can't participate in certain activities vital to eternal salvation on the "Celestial Kingdom."
The Word of Wisdom grew out of the temperance movement that was in vogue at the time it was issued. Like that movement, it advised against consuming tobacco, alcohol, and hot drinks. It also counseled against consuming meats, except "in times of winter, or of cold, or famine.” It was largely ignored, however, until it was made a commandment early in the 20th century. Brigham Young, for example, owned a distillery.
Modern official church interpretations pretty much ignore the part about meat. Also, the WoW has been reinterpreted to include coffee and tea whether drunk hot or cold. But it doesn't apply to hot chocolate drinks — which, incidentally, contain caffeine.
The scripture also identifies various blessings that will come from adherence to the WoW, including health and strength, wisdom and knowledge, and even hidden treasures, but that part gets little attention.
As far as caffeine is concerned, church leaders haven't always been consistent. In the past, an effort was made to find a scientific basis for the ban on coffee and tea, and caffeine got the blame since it is common to both, and soft drinks that contain caffeine were also banned — most obviously on the BYU campus. Caffeinated soft drinks have only recently been allowed there.
The attitudes of church leaders and individual members towards caffeinated soft drinks have varied since about the mid-1950s but have more recently been trending toward acceptance. Still, many individual members avoid them and justify that avoidance by citing the Word of Wisdom. It’s not surprising that one Mormon friend says they’re okay and another says they’re not.

I'm afraid you've got your facts wrong. Facebook and Google didn't shut down AI chatbots because they created their own language. There was an incident in 2017 when Facebook researchers temporarily paused an experiment involving chatbots when the bots began to generate language that was not intelligible to humans. This was not due to the bots creating their own language but rather a result of the researchers not achieving their intended outcomes.
Both companies continue to invest in AI research and chatbot development, but they take precautions to ensure AI systems communicate effectively and ethically. The incident served as a valuable lesson in AI development and the need for careful monitoring.

This is true for a lot of people.
I can make a guess at why, but be warned that I am guessing here, and evolutionary cognitive scientists might point and laugh at me.
Gravity comes up all the time, in very important ways, in our lives, and the lives of our ancestors. If you walk over the edge of a cliff, you fall and die. If you shake a tree hard enough to dislodge fruit, it falls to the ground. And so on. Things fall down.
So, it’s not surprising that animals have evolved some innate “knowledge” that things fall down, and a little more detail to it than that (but not Einstein’s field equations or anything). And we seem to be born with at least some sense of it: If an infant sees a ball move right and then curve in mid air and come back left, they’re surprised, but if they see it move up and then curve in mid air and come back down, they’re not.
And then, your early experiences often involve gravity. You toss things into the air and catch them, you drop things and don’t have them in front of you anymore, you fall down and get a sore elbow. And, being not just an animal but a human, you refine that innate sense into an intuitive model that is, eventually, partly consciously accessible. And when you go to school, that model is refined further. Since you’re just building on an existing model, even the parts that weren’t immediately obvious, as long as they fit with the stuff you already intuitively knew, you can (with a bit of work—whether doing homework for elementary school science class, or practicing to catch a fly ball) add them to what you intuitively know going forward.
Magnetism, on the other hand, rarely comes up, and it’s rarely important. Some animals do seem to have magnetism-related senses, but nothing on our lineage seems to. And you have very few experiences with magnets in your infancy and childhood. And the few you do, it’s playing with a toy, not falling down and hurting yourself. So, you don’t have an intuitive model of magnetism. When you go to school, they have to teach you from scratch, and what you’re seeing never feels intuitively obvious. Everything you know about magnets is stuff you learned abstractly, not stuff you built on top of an intuitive model derived from an innate sense.
Plus, our culture has only known about magnetism at all for a few thousand years, and only known more about it than playing with lodestones as toys for a few hundred, so we haven’t yet made teaching pre-school children about magnetism part of our general child socialization package—that part could conceivably have had enough time to be visibly changing, making it less common for each generation to think magnets our magic, but still have a long way to go before almost nobody is baffled by them.

That being said (correctly or not), if you play with anything enough, you can improve your understanding of it.
Whatever you learned in school (high school physics?), did up the old textbook and go back and practice doing easy homework problems to work out the math. And, after each one, play with an actual setup involving bar magnets, electromagnets, iron filings, metal bars, whatever, until you can demonstrate it to yourself. You may eventually be able to see the visible experimental results in the physical problem. And then the physics model may change from being abstract math you have to memorize into a mental model you can play with. If you turn up the current, will the magnetic wand tug harder toward the bar, or move the filings around differently, or whatever? Once you can answer questions like that without thinking, and even estimate by how much despite not being asked, just by sort of seeing and feeling the effects, it’s a lot harder for it to feel like magic.
I’m not guaranteeing this will help you (or that it’ll be worth your time, even if it does), but it might.

No energy needs to be created or destroyed anywhere, and I’m not sure why you’d even think it does.
Have you ever eaten food? You know how food has a calorie count? What that number means is how much energy you absorb from the food by digesting it. You break down the chemical bonds in the sugars, starches, etc. in the food, releasing the energy stored in those bonds, and acquiring it for yourself. Through tasty, tasty murder of plants, animals, and fungi, you steal their energy.
Plants do things a little different. They use sunlight energy to produce sugar, and then digest that sugar to acquire the energy for themselves.
And some simple microbes acquire energy more directly from sunlight, or from ion channels or even thermal gradients in things like deep sea vents.

Mainly, those charts of the chronology of the early universe that used to list the dark ages as “120 to 500 million years?” now say “120 to 200 million years?”
If galaxies already existed 300-odd million years after the start, and we’re somewhat confident that they shouldn’t exist until at least a little bit into the stelliferous age, then the border between the dark ages and the stelliferous age can’t be that much more than 200 million years.
But that’s pretty much it as far as the big bang itself.
The biggest issue is galaxy formation models. We have way too many of them, and not enough data to rule any of them out. But the JWST data challenges the ones that take too long to get started—if they can’t be modified to go faster, they’ll be ruled out. In very general terms, flat-distribution models (where stars of all sizes begin forming at around the same time, rather than huge stars preferentially forming first) and bottom-up models (where small galaxies form gradually around those huge stars and then merge into larger galaxies, rather than dark matter forming the rough galactic structure and then stars starting to appear all over that structure) tend to predict longer times, and therefore have more problems coping with a shorter span. But it’s still early days, and everything in this paragraph may seem laughably misguided in a couple years. Except that first sentence. The JWST data is almost certainly going to help us constrain the set of plausible galaxy formation models in some important way, even if this initial guess at which way turns out to be wrong.

If the beginning is infinite in size, then when you pause time and try to measure the exact distance from one end to the other (and let’s not worry about how you measure anything when there’s no time), you can go on forever without ever reaching the end. Because a universe that starts out infinite stays infinite.
How will you know when you’ve gone far enough that you can quit? You won’t. If you’ve gone a trillion light years without finding an edge, you still don’t know whether the universe is infinite, a quintillion light years, or a trillion and one light years.
Even if the beginning is finite in size, it’s probably shaped like a hypersphere—like the 2D surface of the Earth, but in 3D—or maybe some more topologically complicated space.
What happens if you try to measure the circumference of the Earth by starting in Ecuador and walking east until you reach the end? You can keep going east forever, without ever reaching the end. Every 40000km, of course, you pass Ecuador again, but you’re looking for the end, and there isn’t one, no matter how many times you go around. A universe that starts out finite probably stays finite, but that doesn’t mean it magically gains an edge at some point.
So, looking for an end that does not exist is not a way to tell is the universe is infinite or finite. You will take infinite time failing to find the end, and, even if you had more than infinite time to spend so you could know you’d failed, it still wouldn’t tell you whether the universe is infinite or finite.
The obvious thing to look for is curvature. Is the universe curved enough to close back in on itself, or not? And we can do that. The problem is that we find that curvature is either 0 or very, very near 0. We can narrow down those error bars more and more with better equipment, but we can never eliminate them entirely. That tells us that the universe is either infinite, or so huge that the curvature is invisible at the scales we can measure. Which is good enough to treat it as infinite for all practical purposes, but we still want to know whether it actually is infinite, right? Which means we’ll have to come up with something cleverer than this. Just trying to measure infinity isn’t it, but that doesn’t mean you should give up trying to come up with something cleverer. (Although if you really do want to contribute, the way to do that is to learn enough of the science to understand what we know, how we know it, and what it means, rather than to make wild guesses and ask other people to evaluate them.)

Every point in the universe is the center of its observable universe.
That’s true by the definition of observable universe; you don’t need any “if” here at all.
Maybe you didn’t mean observable there? Is every point the center of the entire infinite universe? Here, it depends on how you define “center”. There are a few different choices to make, but basically if you require any kind of uniqueness, there is no center; if you don’t, every point is the center; the other choices don’t actually matter for this question.
But even here, “if the universe is infinite” is too strong a condition. Because the exact same thing is true if the universe is closed, finite but with no border, because it wraps back on itself like the surface of the Earth (but in one more dimension). Pick a direction. Start walking along the ground in that direction. You never reach an edge and fall off—because every 40,000km you find yourself crossing your starting point and going round again. That’s a finite surface, with no edge. Now pick a direction in 3D space. Start flying a spaceship in that direction. You never reach an edge and fall off—because every (say) quadrillion light years you find yourself crossing your starting point and going round again. That’s a finite space, with no edge. And, just as with an infinite space, that means either there is no center, or every point is the center, depending on your definition.
There’s generally only a unique center if there’s an edge.
Every point’s observable universe does have an edge—the sphere that’s (currently) 46 billion light years in diameter centered on that point. And of course that point is the unique center of that sphere.
But the entire universe almost certainly does not have an edge—infinite or finite. So it doesn’t have a unique center.

If “100% time” means anything, what it means the normal state of things—it means Newton’s approximation to gravity is correct instead of just very close to correct. It definitely does not mean that gravity turns into antigravity. That seems to be the core of your question, and, if so, the answer is no.
More generally: You can sometimes get infinity as an output out of 0 as an input, because you’re dividing by that 0. For example, any mass packed into 0 volume means infinite density, because density is just mass divided by volume. But you can’t ever turn that around and get infinity out of 1 (that is, 100%) the same way, because dividing by 1 doesn’t do anything exciting; anything divided by 1 is just itself. And yet, that’s what you seem to be trying to do here.
And the rest of the question, I can’t find any way to interpret it that makes sense. I can imagine reasonable things that “a singularity approaches 0 time” could mean, but none of them seem like they could be at all relevant here. Exponential expansion is what happened during inflation, a very brief phase that ended 13.8 billion years ago, not what’s been happening for the last 5–6 billion years. Inflation wasn’t explained by dark energy, and especially not by dark matter. Dark matter is closer to the exact opposite of what you seem to think it is—it doesn’t cause expansion; it’s matter, just like normal matter, with normal mass, and enough mass for everything up to the size of galaxy clusters to resist expansion entirely.

If by Spaghetti Osteria you mean a place to eat a good plate of spaghetti or pasta, know that generally any place in Italy will serve you satisfactorily.

Pasta is a very common dish in Italy and everyone knows how to cook it very well, even at home.
However, I can give you some tips to further improve your experience.
Avoid restaurants near popular tourist spots.

Choose a small restaurant (or trattoria or osteria, the name does not matter) located in quieter areas and frequented by locals.
For example a spaghetteria or a vineria (wine bar) in the suburbs. You will eat very well and spend very little.

There is an infinite number of types of bread in Italy.
These are some of the most common and popular types (but all are delicious).
Altamura bread has a thick, crisp, dark crust. It is baked in wood-fired ovens that give it an extraordinary fragrance and aroma.

“Panini” are light-colored, have a thin, crisp crust and are ideal for stuffing with cold cuts and cheeses.

“Filoni” resemble French baguettes but have a different flavor and crispness.

Milk “panini” are ideal for sweet or savory fillings; they are also good for stuffing with meats and sausages.

The flours used also vary widely. In addition to traditional 00 flour, there are harder flours, there is semolina flour and whole wheat flours.
Whatever meal is served at the table, there should always be a basket with good fresh bread.

Every region and area of Italy has a typical traditional bread. And each of them is extraordinarily good.
In the past, bread was the staple food of the most modest families.
Bread, tomato and olive’s oil, for example, was a cheap and rewarding meal.

Tradition and respect for bread have been passed down through the centuries, and for this reason bread is still a staple of Italian cuisine and comes in all its countless variations.

I am not aware of any houses in Italy without a kitchen. Moreover, given the special care and importance Italians assign to food, the kitchen is a fundamental space in the home. Even in the smallest apartments there is at least one kitchenette, if there is no space for a larger kitchen.
A typical old style italian kitchen:

Even in my experience of living in France, where I spent longer or shorter periods of time for vacation and work, all the homes I stayed in had a kitchen.

Well, it's quite simple, really.
Priceline.com, Expedia.com, and Orbitz.com are like three different flavors of ice cream in the world of online travel agencies.
Priceline.com is like that mysterious scoop of ice cream in the corner of the freezer that surprises you with a unique taste.
They pioneered the Name Your Own Price feature, which allows you to bid on hotel rooms and flights.
It's like haggling for a better deal, but in the digital age.
Expedia.com, on the other hand, is your classic vanilla ice cream.
It's reliable, consistent, and offers a wide range of options.
You know exactly what you're getting, and it's always there when you need it.
Orbitz.com, well, that's your adventurous scoop with sprinkles and a cherry on top.
They focus on bundling travel components, so it's like creating your own travel sundae with flights, hotels, and car rentals all in one.
So, while they all serve the same purpose, each of these online travel agencies has its own flavor of doing things.
It ultimately comes down to your personal taste and what kind of travel experience you're craving.
Happy travels!

Well, let me start off by saying that choosing between Ola and Uber is like trying to decide between a rollercoaster and a Ferris wheel.
They both serve the same purpose of getting you from point A to point B, but the experience can be vastly different.
Uber, with its sleek black cars and fancy branding, might make you feel like a VIP every time you hop in.
Plus, they've been around for quite some time and have a massive fleet of drivers, which means you'll rarely have to wait too long for a ride.
However, their surge pricing during peak hours can make your wallet cry more than watching a sad puppy video.
On the other hand, Ola is like the scrappy underdog that's always trying to surprise you.
They have a wide variety of vehicle options, from compact hatchbacks to rickshaws, giving you more choices than a buffet.
While their service might not always be as polished as Uber's, they make up for it with competitive pricing and innovative features like Ola Share, which can save you some extra dough.
Ultimately, the better choice depends on your preferences and priorities.
If you want consistency and fancy rides, Uber might be your best bet.
But if you're all about variety and saving money, Ola could be the way to go.
Just remember, no matter which one you choose, you're still riding in a car driven by a stranger, so buckle up and enjoy the adventure!

Rome wasn't built in a day, and neither is a future civilization!Sure, with a head start on modern science, the Romans might have had steam engines, algebra, and who knows, maybe even a crude version of the internet.

You see, it's not just about having the knowledge; it's about the societal, cultural, and economic changes needed to harness that knowledge effectively.
So, while it would be a cool experiment, don't expect to book your time-travel vacation to ancient Rome just yet!

It is incorrect. The verb tense is wrong and unnecessary repetition never sounds good to native speakers of English. Here are some correct options in better writing style.
“I didn't take any new photos to upload as my profile picture.”
I didn't take = simple past tense. I never took the photos, or didn't take them within a previously specified range of time in the past.
photos to upload = the purpose of taking the photos would have been so that I could upload them. So maybe I did take photos, but I didn't take any for the purpose of making a new profile picture.
“I haven't taken any new photos that I can upload as my profile picture.”
I haven't taken = Simple present perfect tense. I didn't take photos in the recent past. Maybe I did take some, long ago. It might also mean I didn't take any new photos, so I don't have any new photos now. (action in the past with continuing effects in the present).
that I can upload = This doesn't specify that the purpose of taking the photos would have been a new profile picture. Maybe I haven't taken any pictures recently. Maybe I took some, but none were suitable for use as a profile picture.
“I didn't have any new photos taken to upload as my profile picture.”

1. They developed bad speech habits in childhood. These are hard to change, after about age 10.
2. They grew up in communities that are historically under-educated, and in many cases remain in such communities. That means even if they are taught better than their ancestors were, they are constantly surrounded by people who reinforce the errors that are common in their communities.
3. They grew up in communities that are sufficiently insulated to develop their own dialects with distinctive variants in grammar, syntax, phonemes and vocabulary. This is not only a regional phenomenon but can be found even different parts of the same, major city.
4. Speech habits are the single greatest factor that instinctively trigger people to evaluate others as “like me” or “not like me” (insider vs outsider). Therefore the speech habits of the family and community of origin are deeply embedded in most people's sense of self. Changing one's speech habits seems tantamount to abandoning one's roots. Some people can shift smoothly back and forth between standard English and the patois of their youth, but most cannot.
5. Likewise, communities — especially those that see themselves as oppressed — hold on to their distinctive speech patterns and persecute people who attempt to speak standard English. They see such people as devaluing and denigrating their communities of origin. They see them as becoming outsiders and adopting “outside” culture and values over their communities’.
You should look into how Deaf people have opposed cochlear implants and harassed those who obtain them for insight into these phenomena. 
I personally knew a Black woman from Seattle who joined the Army. She spoke excellent, standard English, as did her family and neighbors. She was stationed in North Carolina and found that she would be criticized and harassed by the Southern Blacks, who speak a dialect that is notoriously rife with nonstandard inflections, conjugations and syntax. She, apparently wasn't “Black enough”, because of how she spoke.
Added to all of that — and definitely related to it — is the fact that correcting the speech of others has come to be seen as rude, arrogant, judgmental and oppressive. Therefore people don't tend to correct each other, except for parents (who will probably reinforce the errors of their communities) and teachers (who are likely to be dismissed as agents of the “outsiders”, working for the government and imposing elements of “standard culture” on people who would rather stay distinctive.)
Employers who correct the speech of others or who pass over employees at promotion time due to poor speech habits or writing skills are vulnerable to accusations of racism. The detrimental effect on morale, and the dangers of lawsuits are definitely likely to cool the employer's ardor for standard English in the workplace. The existence of the term “grammar Nazi” validates this perception is real. Those who correct the speech of others are trying to oppress and eliminate people who are different from their own norm, albeit by assimilation rather than murder.
Therefore you find people who:
· …may not know what errors they make, because no one corrects them.
· …aren't motivated to change because they don't see any detriment to themselves because of their errors. They won't lose jobs or promotions, even if they and others suffer from their poor communication skills.
· … are actually incentivised to resist change by their socioeconomic and ethnoracial communities (to coin a phrase), with both positive and negative reinforcement.
I'm as much of a grammatical pedant as you are, because I believe that sloppy, careless speech leads to sloppy, careless thinking, not only to poor communication. Sadly, I am also enough of a realist to know that I will not have a significant effect on this trend.

“Agilely” is an adverb, but it is awkward to say, so we rarely use it. It modifies the verb “leapt”.
“Exceptionally” is an adverb. It modifies the adverb “well”.
“Well” is an adverb, modifying the verb “did”.
“Exceptionally well” is an adverbial phrase (a.k.a. phrasal adverb) related to the verb “did”.
“In his exams” is also an adverbial phrase modifying the verb “did”.
It isn't true that every adverb ends in “ly”, nor is it true that every word ending in “ly” is an adverb. Nevertheless, “ly” is the ending we use to change an adjective into an adverb, so a HIGH percentage of words ending in “ly” are adverbs. When you are looking for adverbs, it would be a good idea to look for the words ending in “ly”, and check them to see whether they modify a verb, adjective or adverb. If they modify any of these, they are adverbs.
Then look for other words that modify verbs, adjectives or verbs.

Yes, you can extend a sentence before a quotation, after a quotation, or both. However, your verb tenses are wrong and the question is ambiguous. “What is today's lunch” could mean, “What is the purpose of today's lunch?” or it could mean, “What food will we receive for lunch today?”

> She asked, “What is for lunch today?” when I was thinking the same thing.

This refers to an event in the past that happened as another action was ongoing. “Asked” is simple past tense, and “was thinking” is continuous past tense.
“What is for lunch?” is an inquiry about the food we will receive. If we are having a luncheon for a special purpose, “What is today's lunch about?” is an inquiry about the purpose of the luncheon.

“I like the Apple that you bring”, may be correct, but only:
· if you are using “Apple” as a proper noun, such as referring to an electronic device by its brand name,
AND
· if you are referring to a recurring action. The person brings the Apple device repeatedly.
If using “apple” to refer to the fruit, instead of the brand name, you should not capitalize the word.
If referring to a single action that is happening as the speaker is speaking, use the simple present continuous tense, “you are bringing”.
“Those” is not correct. “Those” is the plural of the pronoun “that”. There is no plural to which “those” can refer. Also, what this sentence requires is NOT a pronoun.
This sentence requires the conjunction, “that”, used as a function word to introduce a subordinate clause as a complement to a noun or adjective. The phrase, “that you bring”, is a complement to the noun, “Apple” (or “apple”).
Conjunctions have no plural forms.

Yes, but It’s a question of what sound you are looking for.
You have the choice of so many configurations. And dependent on the configuration, it is going to give you different tones. You have single coils, humbuckers, mini hums, P-90s etc.
Humbuckers have two single coils which result in a thicker, deeper, and smoother sound, whereas Single Coils are brighter and crisper.
Now, you can have a both in a guitar or one of these combinations. It’s also dependent on the build. Some builds such as a strat can have 3 single coils but could also have a single neck and middle pickup and the bridge a humbucker. You can have 2 humbuckers or 3 humbuckers. You can have a GLP Standard with p-90s which is a tone of its own. So it is also dependent on the components you choose and how good they are. Standard? PAF? D’Marzios?
Do you want a beefy sound, do you want a mix? Do you want one or the other? A lot of LPs are double hums.
But the true trick is using your switches amp and tone knobs. That’s what will give you tons of sounds/tones and if you mix them correctly, headspace etc, reverb, echo, etc you can get so many tones out og a single or double coil.
But yes it matters. There’s so much more on this topic as it’s really unique for each build. You have to consider woods etc. So many components go into the build of a guitar and the tones that it can and will produce.
Having 11 customs myself, each one is unique in its structure and sound, even though many of the bodies are LPs, strats and teles, they are all different.

The basics are the following, as it’s a vast topic.
It all took place in Detroit, Michigan. Detroit was heavily populated with blacks with the percentage rising almost 30% from 1910 to 1960.
Given that “Motor City” Detroit was the automobile center of the USA, many blacks worked there, as they were drawn to the trade and the fact there were so many job opportunities.
And by the late 60s, it was home to Motown Records, spear headed by the great Berry Gordy Jr. Racial tension and segregation was a serious problem. You had the white side of the tracks and the other side of the tracks.
Given that social divide, many black artists had a terribly difficult time breaking into the music industry. Berry Gordy had the vision to make this happen and to give these artist the chance to be heard across the world.
Motown Records was home to such artists as Stevie Wonder, Diana Ross, The Supremes, Marvin Gaye, The Temptations and so many more.
If it wasn’t for Gordy and Motown Records, we may have never been privy to such talents.

In the Southern United States breakfast is the meal most commonly enjoyed socially among the retirees. It is a leisurely affair and it’s pretty big too. When the heat of the day has progressed one isn’t really expected to enjoy midday lunch. It’s just too damned hot. Among tradesmen it’s the same thing. WaWa or 7–11 has roll ups and breakfast sandwiches that you eat in the truck on the way to the job. Or in the parking lot before they punch in. People also hydrate a lot in the South. So really who has room a heavy lunch? A couple of Egg McMuffins at 7:30 AM and an extra large coffee, and they’re good to go. No fancy stuff. Calories, proteins and fats, and coffee.
Weekends and holidays are good sensible leisurely breakfasts. Uh-Oh- Family stuff like take Stefanie to practice or a game at 8:30 AM or Mikey has SAT class at nine. There goes that morning.

It took me many years of Northern USA to learn a lot about vegetable growing. Then I moved to Florida. I took all my New Jersey experience with me and I was a dismal failure. Today I start planting in January. By July 1st I’m done. Later in September I’ll start again. Winter plants are tomatoes and peppers and things like that. September plants will be greens and brassicas. Peas and beans grow fast so I can plant those twice. July and August are unrelenting in hot days and nights. Plants need a breather from the heat. So even if the Florida days are hot, the nights in fall, winter and spring are cooler.

In January of 1972 down in Miami, Hollywood, Florida to be more specific, I attended the first show that the Allman Brothers Band did after the death of Duane Allman. It was at the Hollywood Sportatorium. They were putting the finishing touches on their album Eat A Peach which they were recording at Criteria Studios in Miami with producer Tom Dowd.. There was still a lot of questions as to whether or not they would, or could, carry on after Duanes death. In this show Gregg Allman was still not himself. His singing was still a little weak and he was stationed hidden behind his Hammond B3 at the back corner of the stage. The show started a little slow and the band seemed tentative. About a third of the way through it seemed as though Dickie Bettes was struck by some type of magical lightening bolt. He totally took charge of the stage. He of course was trying to do what it had always taken 2 excellent players to do. As he gained confidence he seemed to move closer to the audience. His playing was magnificent and gave me chill bumps. All questions about the bands playing ability to carry on without Duane were answered. The sound without Duanes slide mastery was a bit different but Bettes brought an exciting energy to the songs that fans could still marvel over. I believe they only played about 7 songs focusing more on instrumentals such as Mountain Jam and In Memory of Elizabeth Reed. It was fabulous and I remember having the musical chill bumps several times that night. I believe there is still an archived recording of this show at the Allman Brothers website.

Every character doesn’t need a ten page backstory, especially if that character is going to die by the end of the next page. Seriously,m the trick is to allow the reader to create a character along with you.
“John walked into the local police station and walked up to the Desk Officer. “John Smith, US Marshal's Service.” He showed his badge. The Desk Officer looked up at him as he stood 6′-10″ tall and weighed almost three hundred, forty pounds.. it was then the Desk Officer noticed his long platinum blond hair. “Is the Sheriff in?” John asked. “Hang on Marshal, let me check.” He punched a couple buttons on the phone. He spoke into the phone. He hung up and said, Sheriff’s waiting for you. “Step through this door, you know the procedure.”
Now in that very short paragraph you know a great deal about John Smith, not that I told you too much about him but he was a US Marshal and he was a giant with long platinum blond hair. I can assure you by the time I got him back to the Sheriff’s office, you know a great deal more about him and it’ mostly from you becoming a partner in the description. You mind will fill in many things on it’s own with simple prompts.
It’s not a new idea in writing but also understand that we all know what a football looks and feels like, so you don’t have to go into a detailed rundown on the football to describe it to the reader. They got it, it’s a football. See what I mean? I could very easily have turned John’s introduction into a two page affair with cops coming out to gwalk at the freakishly large US Marshall and him flirting with a couple of the female officers.

Don’t write anything from a male or female perspective, just write the story. If it’s a female character then make her sound female, if it’s a male character then butch it up a bit.
Male and female characters are different but I write both characters all the time and it never makes me wonder if I got the females, females enough. I write then as I have gotten to know females over the years of interaction with them.
However, that is wisdom that comes from many years of experience with females, in my younger days I had a terrible time understanding females? Yes, doesn’t mean yes always, no, doesn’t mean not always, and God help you if you get a “Maybe”. That is a road to a neverending story.

· “Blind” doesn’t necessarily mean totally without vision. Even a tiny smidge of vision is a huge help. Let’s talk about a totally blind person.
· A blind person may choose not to order particularly difficult-to-manage food in a socially critical situation. This is not much of a barrier: penne instead of spaghetti, chicken & rice soup instead of chicken noodle, etc.
· Just as a sighted person manages the myriad of things to be aware of when driving without being consciously aware of them, a blind person knows the locations of things on their plate and their body position relative to the dishes without thinking about it. Eating soup is no harder than touching your nose with your eyes closed. You know where it is even if you cannot see it.
· Food is served in a conventional way, on a flat plate, with a fork on the left and the knife and spoon on the right. Water glasses, wine glasses, and coffee cups are conveniently different shapes and temperatures, and also have a standard place at the table. These conventions are somewhat more important to a blind person. Yes, if you mix things up, it will be a little harder for a blind person until they sort their place setting out.
· A plate can be explored with a knife and fork, and it looks just like dining if you aren’t looking for the technique. A gentle touch with a single finger is hardly noticeable.
· A blind person might own plates with a steep rim around them to make capturing stray peas and such easier. These plates are widely available because they work well for the elderly and for all kinds of disabilities. You might not even notice these plates are different, just more convenient.
· A blind person’s dinner companions get quickly used to helping unobtrusively. Instead of passing a side dish they offer to serve, instead of handing a dish through the air, they push it along the table so the sound identifies its location. They may not even be aware they are assisting. It’s just what works.
· Finally, a blind person will not let blindness stand in the way of enjoying their food. If they can’t find something, they’ll ask. If they have to touch things, that’s what they do. Blind people generally have a sense of humor about their situation that puts other people at ease.

Rub the chicken with oil or butter, salt it inside and out, and sprinkle on herbs or other seasonings. Put it on a rack in a pan with high sides, and into a 350F oven for just about an hour. Remove from the oven and put it on a platter to rest for at least 15 minutes, tented with foil to retain heat. Carve and serve.

Salt - fat - acid - heat.
Salt brings out and enhances the flavor of any dish, just be careful about how much you put in.
Fat, like a swirl of butter in a sauce or a drizzle of oil to finish the dish and bring out flavor.
Acid can also make a dish more flavorful - lemon juice, a splash of vinegar, or lime zest.
Probably complementary spices or herbs. Not to make the dish particularly spicy hot (to me a sign of a bad cook or inferior ingredients both of which need to be hidden), but to enhance the flavors of the dish, or in the case of herbs to add some freshness.

There are different techniques to cooking thin or thick steaks. You should have a hot side and cooler side on your grill. For charcoal, put all the coals on one side of the grill. For gas, turn on the burners only on one side. You will need an instant read thermometer to check the internal temperature of the meat.
First, you need to season the steaks. Plain salt and pepper is fine, unless you have a seasoning blend you prefer.
For the thin steaks (1″ or less), cook covered for 2–3 minutes on the hot side, and flip for another 2–3 minutes on the hot side. Remove and temp - 132F is medium rare. Let rest for 5 minutes for the temperature to come up, and serve.
For thicker steaks, do the same 2–3 minutes (per inch of thickness) per side on the hot side, then move to the cooler side for another 2–3 minutes and check the temperature. If it needs longer, leave them on the cool side for another minute or 2, and check again.

The formal title of the King’s wife is properly HM The Queen.
If she is widowed of him in the future the custom is then to use the given name, as in Queen Camilla. There is no point trying to apply any logic since few princesses by birth become queen consorts.
But it is not actually true that “only blood princesses can use the title Princess <first name>” - as witness the case of Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester, who was granted a dispensation to use her given name rather than be Princess Henry when she became the dowager Duchess of Gloucester.

Anxiety and depression are qualitatively different from “feeling anxious” or “feeling down.” Feeling anxious or down usually have a specific reason, and may benefit from behavioral and dietary changes — or avoiding / getting away from the cause.
Having anxiety or depression is usually caused by chemical imbalances in the brain. (This can’t be self-diagnosed; consult a doctor with experience in these fields.) Just as people with diabetes can’t regulate their blood sugar with good thoughts and clean living, neither can people with anxiety or depression regulate their brain chemistry by plain force of will. And doing nothing — “waiting until it gets better” — is just setting the patient up for failure and continuing misery.
Being unable to overcome anxiety or depression by oneself is NOT a personal failing, or a sign of weakness. The brain isn’t functioning properly, just as a bone cannot function properly when it’s broken. We put a cast on a broken bone. We treat chemical imbalances, whether diabetes or anxiety, by introducing chemicals to restore the balance.
If this is you, or a friend, don’t suffer through it. Find a competent doctor and get the treatment they advise. I have a friend and a niece who deal with these issues; the proper medication makes a huge difference in their quality of life (for the better). Truly, it’s worth it.
Q: Is it better to take medication for anxiety and depression or just wait until it gets better?

It happened to me once, in all the many years I rode.
That day I had a very severe cold, but I was determined not to miss my scheduled riding lesson. (There’s a reason teenage girls are often considered horse-crazy, LOL!) I assume the cold affected my inner ear (balance mechanism); I got about halfway through the lesson and had to quit; I felt so seasick. My instructor said, “You don’t look so good,” and I almost fell out of the saddle rather than dismounting.
So it can happen, but I suspect (although I have no proof) that it would be rare, and when the rider is already feeling sub-par. In general, the rider’s body is moving in rhythm with the horse, at natural gaits and speeds (even galloping), so there’s no vision/balance system disconnect to lead to motion sickness.
Q: Can you get motion sick riding on a horse?

You apparently think that the clitoris must come in contact with the saddle when the girl/woman is riding. Absolutely not; she uses her thigh and leg muscles to maintain a completely different position.
But consider if what you think happens actually did — the girl/woman would be lifted slightly into the air from the action of the gallop, and land with her body weight smashing her clitoris into the hard leather of the saddle, over and over and over. Can you imagine the pain????? Rather similar to if a boy’s/man’s testicles were smashed between his body weight and the saddle with every stride of the horse galloping. If that were the case, riding horses would never have become popular; most people do not like pain occurring in the genital area, and do not seek it out.
However as others have said, galloping (or loping/cantering — slightly slower and more controlled) is mentally very pleasant. It’s the rush of speed + having a big, powerful animal under your control and working in sync with you + freedom in natural surroundings. I’ve found it thrilling and exciting and explosively joyful — but not the tiniest bit sexually pleasurable.
Q: Have you gone horse riding? If so, is galloping as pleasant for girls as I think it is?

“Cool” is when we can choose to experience or not experience something, according to what we want at the time.
When you have no control over it, it’s not at all cool. About 50% of the time, I have either [a] a distinct black spot that bounces around in my visual field or [b] a larger blurry area that also bounces around to get in the way of what I’m trying to see. If it stayed still, the brain would adjust and ignore it, but no such luck. And sometimes, my floaters — spot or blurry — are accompanied by the eye feeling “gummy”. I suspect that’s more in my head than in my eye, but it’s there, and quite irritating.
As another answer pointed out, floaters can also be a sign of retinal detachment, so that’s a (fairly minor) worry that I have checked yearly. (Although a sudden cascade of floaters would be a “call the doctor immediately” emergency.)
There’s a reason that most people dislike floaters. Don’t be in such a hurry to experience them yourself.
Q: Is it possible to make eye floaters occur at will? They look pretty cool to me.

Each news segment claims that she’s the only one known on the entire planet. So I’ve only seen her pictures.

yes, that’s what it’s like. it’s a serious disorder. trying to soothe it is like putting a band-aid on a gushing artery. you wouldn’t do that if your gf were bleeding to death would you? or just open a window for some air if she were having an asthma attack, or just tell her to lie down and rest if she were having chest pains and signs of a heart attack? no, you would recognize that she needed more help than you could give, and call an ambulance. there ARE some soothing and coping techniques but they are to be used by HER, not you. she is the one who needs to learn to deal with these dis-regulated episodes. it’s nice that you want to help, but it’s only a band-aid. take care of your own mental health, encourage her to get professional help, and realize there’s only so much (not much) you can do. this isn’t a fairy tale where enough love, the right words, the right man, will save her. without professional help, you’ll both just drain each other till nothing is left, and she’ll move on. in general, for the provocation, accusation, and silent treatments, letting her “cool off” may be best, as trying to soothe her is likely to only ramp up her efforts to receive more soothing, and there will never be enough. if you think the self-harm threats are serious, call help for her. it may save her life if she’s serious, and if not, she should learn not to do it again. yes, these things can be a cry for attention, but a relationship based on you giving her attention on demand will leave you tired and bitter eventually. if she’s old enough to date, she should take responsibility for trying to get the help needed to learn to be a better partner. maybe go to therapy sessions with her if she’s already going (and since she has a diagnoses i assume she is or has gone at some time) and bring these questions up. if therapy isn’t working, she may consider changing to a therapist who specializes in treating bpd. not every therapist (even if they “like” them”) is effective at improving the pwbpd’s quality of life as much as possible.

your concern seems to be about your twin, but if you lash out and say awful things to anyone, you may want to focus on yourself and why it happened, rather than on someone else. it likely happened to show you what needs healing in you so that you can avoid doing it again, as it is not something that will affect your life in a good way. be terrified for yourself and what such uncontrolled anger might do to loved ones, not about what someone else will do, you have no control over that anyway. you do, however, have a good clue as to what you need to work on. use this opportunity to look at your own issues, and if your tf forgives you, that’s fine, but i don’t think that’s the most important thing at the moment. and if they are forgiving, seeing that you are taking it seriously and trying to change will make them feel better about it. there’s nothing wrong with stating your mind, but try to do so before so much anger builds up that you explode again. learn emotional control, a very basic concept which will serve you well always, but that is often not emphasized enough in our culture.

your twin is likely rejecting you because you are still concerned with them rejecting you. whatever you fear or worry about most is what they will probably do. only when you don’t really notice if they reject you or not will they have a chance at coming around! if you are so involved with life that you rarely think about them, they may surprise you one day. but if you still are in the “wanting” energy, it keeps them away. ironic isn’t it? you can’t have what you yearn for most, since the yearning for love is what needs healing in you. my suggestion would be to resume your inner work and move forward, not back. anything is possible, but you can’t put your life on hold waiting for it.

In the 1950s and 60s there were a lot of new technologies developed and due to a lot of bomb damage from WWII there was a lot of development using short cuts and cheap materials. In this case a product which had an expected life of 30 years has not been replaced for over 50 years. This is due to government’s perpetually windging about there being no money to maintain buildings properly. It has caught up with them and even now they are using short term fixes to avoid doing the repairs properly.

There were more men in reserved occupations than in WWI because of changing technology. WWI was a war of manpower. WWII was a war of production and technology. The aircraft industry is a good example. In WWI it was a tiny one, by WWII it was massive. Still huge numbers of all social classes served.
My family was unusual in that both the men of that generation were in reserved occupations. My father was a graduate engineer working for AVROs as a stress engineer - in lay terms he did the calculations which determined whether an aircraft would fly or fall to bits trying. He survived the blitz although his best mate did not - killed by bombing while on fire watch. My uncle was a merchant navy officer - he died when his ship was sunk in the Atlantic.
While women were not conscripted as such single women had the choice between joining the women’s branches of the armed forces or being allocated war work, some of which was more dangerous than actually fighting.

Social anthropology examines the way that cultural is structured, how people interact, and the underlying assumptions and power structures. These are vital for understanding how the world works and why, and it is also part of the reason why some people in positions of power want this type of research defunded.

Provenance can have two meanings in archaeology: 1) original source, and, more often, 2) where it was found in a site.
For many artifacts, #1 can be determined even if it has been moved around through either diagnostic aspects of the artifact, chemical sourcing, etc.. For #2, which is the one that archaeologists tend to be more concerned about, without careful notes kept of its discovery, no, it’s provenance cannot be determined.

I cannot speak to the specific guitars that were used on most songs, but in the case of Little Wing, it was NOT recorded with a Telecaster, and I suspect that none of these songs were*.
In Little Wing there is heavy use of a tremolo arm, which the Telecaster does not have. Aftermarket tremolo arms, such as the Bixby, don’t provide as much change in tone as is used in Little Wing. Little Wing had to have been recorded on a Stratocaster. While Hendrix used multiple different guitars, and recorded with a number of them, the Strat was his general go-to.
*Edit: The solo to Purple Haze was recorded on a Telecaster due to Hendrix’s Strat having been damaged right before recording. He borrowed a Telecaster to record the solo. But that’s one out of these five songs, and it appears that only the solo was recorded on the Telecaster.

It depends on what specific academic field you are working in. In archaeology, we only count physical items as artifacts. But you get into sociology and economics, and there are people who would use the term for ideas. But consider the difference between these fields (dealing with long gone people who left only material remains behind vs. dealing with currently living people or abstract models of large numbers of people) and the reason for this difference is pretty obvious. That said, while I have heard sociologists and economists talk about “artifact” ideas, I don’t believe that this is a common term.

Sony Alpha cameras are at the forefront of mirrorless technology. The choice of lenses for them is greater than any other mirrorless system, with 3 levels of native lens, plus Zeiss partnered variants.
All the usual third party lens manufacturers make good lenses that work well with the E-mount system. Then you get top quality 3rd party lenses like Zeiss and Voightlander and Specialists like Laowa.
The latest Alpha models have superb AF and AF recognition and the manual focus environment is excellent (Better than possible in DSLRs).
The latest generation of Alpha lenses take more use of the benefits of mirrorless, making them smaller and lighter.
Downside, some people don’t like the smaller size than DSLRs and many complain that the menus are complicated. Fully articulated screens are only just being brought in (although the old A mount A99 had one) and sony have ditched GPS.

Sony no longer produce DSLRs, but their interchangeable lens mirrorless cameras are equivalent.
If you want to make creative images and have full control, then go for an Interchangeable Lens Camera (when are we going to get a simple abbreviation for these?). If you want to just take snaps, have a camera that easily fits in a pocket and not worry about focus and exposure, then a point and shoot will do.

You can save a lot of money by buying 2nd hand lenses from a reputable camera dealer. (check out the photography magazines for their adverts).
Lower quality lenses are significantly cheaper than better quality, which are significantly cheaper than top quality lenses. However, lower quality lenses can still produce images that most people won’t notice difference.

With the latest editions of cameras I don’t think DSLRs are considered superior to mirrorless. The main reason DSLRs are still bought is that photographers who already have those systems have invested in lenses that fit, so it is easier and more economic to upgrade or replace the camera body with one in that system.

Most camera brands have models that make it relatively easy to use external flash.
They have a hot shoe to which you can attach the flash gun, or a remote transmitter which transmits to one or more flash guns that are mounted on receivers. These systems have ‘through the lens’ metering, so you don’t need to do all the calculations that we used to have to do in the past.

The quality of images from DSLRs and mirrorless cameras, of similar specs, are the same.
Mirrorless cameras can be made smaller and lighter (especially the lenses) for the same quality. Mirrorless is now a mature technology and is more future proof than DSLR, which is old and slowly waning. Having said that, you can get good 2nd hand deals as people switch to mirrorless.

0.3 is in the tenths
0.x8 is in the hundredths place
and 0.xx5 is in the thousandths place
and 0.xx6 is in the ten-thousandths place
So to round at the hundredths you look to the next place (the thousandths place) … it is 5 … if it was exactly 5 you would invoke the even or odd rounding rule.
But it had more digits in the following places (you only need to see a digit in the next ten-thousandths place) so you have to round UP.
So you round the 8 that is currently in the hundredths place up to nine 9 AND remove any trailing digits to get the answer of …
0.39

Like most things, it depends on where you’ve been or where you're going.
Bear in mind that computer science or technical IT is completely unlike data science. I wouldn't say most programmers are awful at statistics (they are) and most data scientists are terrible programmers (they are) but there's less overlap than you think. Go with your strengths here.
If you concentrated on operations research in your BS, then you're pretty well prepared for an analytics or data science MS. Some are even hosted within IE departments, so you should have zero friction getting in. If anything you should try to not overlap too much with what you took in your BS, because it's incredibly boring if you do that.
Here's the thing: taught MS degrees are often (always) cash centers, so they won't come with funding. Wait until your employer will pay for a taught MS. A research MS will, and nobody will think less of you if you leave after your Master's, but be aware that the standards are higher and more is expected of you.

This is a trick question: there are no courses from a local community college which will make a case for a M7 business school.
If you have a low undergraduate GPA, you need to attack the problem on two fronts: first, get as much time between the undergraduate GPA and the b-school application as possible.
Do something interesting: work at a startup, or in the nonprofit sector, or even in government, but show a track record of achievement, increasing responsibility, tenacity, good judgement.
Second, get their attention by maxing out the standardized tests. A GMAT of 770 or above, or a 340/340 GRE. This won't get you in, not even close, but it will get your application read.
Your challenge is to get it read. With a mediocre undergraduate GPA and equally mediocre GMAT, it won't even get read. If you try to game it by taking community college credits, it definitely won't get read. The M7 schools can fill all their seats with grade A prospects; you have to show them that you're also a grade A

Nick R. Feller has the right of it: there are multiple pathways to a job in data science.
I would have put industrial engineering near the top, too, since someone taking OR/MS and optimization is studying pretty much everything a data scientist should study, at a reasonably high level of rigor.
Undergraduate curriculum is designed to take advantage of stacked courses; you can't take organic chemistry without general chemistry. You need both of these to take analytical. Making someone a STEM generalist by requiring only intro chemistry, physics, biology, geology, mathematics, statistics, etc would be laughable. They wouldn't know anything.
Making someone a data science generalist by requiring only a couple of semesters each of intro mathematics, statistics, compsci, software eng, business, then sprinkling a little magic fairy dust on them doesn't prepare them to be a data scientist or much of anything else: not enough compsci to be an entry level programmer, not enough statistics to be an entry level analyst, not enough math/OR to work in decision support, and so on.
And we won't even get into what happens when the data science bubble bursts.
So: ignore a data science major. Pick a topical major that interests you. Take advantage of the stacked courses and opportunities for in depth study in that major. Data science will be waiting for you when you're done, but so will a hundred other career paths.

The core IE courses, which you'll be required to take, will be doable but tough to very tough.
The project management and MIS domain will have some overlap. Ergonomics will have no overlap but you might be able to get through it with hard work, manufacturing will have no overlap and be very tough, especially the simulation course sequence, OR and optimization will be almost impossible since they're graduate level math courses.
It'll be very hard. Not impossible. But hard.

Data scientist here:
You can only be effective when you know your domain well. Really, really well. People have already solved textbook exercises, which is why they're textbook exercises, and why classroom work doesn't always translate to professional work.
If you're working on new problems, you need to know why they haven't been solved yet: are they technically difficult, conceptually difficult, or are they hard problems that aren't worth solving, which is why they're still unsolved.
This might sound weird to a student, but as you get older and more experienced, you'll find you need time getting good to get good.

Thanks for the A2A.
Industrial engineering is a huge discipline - anything that involves the transportation or transformation of people, material, or energy. Which is to say everything. But that also means that there are many industrial engineerings inside industrial engineering.
Want to work on making things? Manufacturing. Moving things? Logistics and modelling. Evaluating things? QC and engineering statistics. How people do things? Ergonomics. Planning and forecasting? Operations research and informatics. OR not enough math for you? Try optimization.
How it differs from the other disciplines of engineering is that it's mainly discrete mathematics and statistics, not calculus. I suppose that this counts as “not a lot of math” to some people.
What industrial engineering absolutely does not have is “a lot of business”. You've heard of management as a three-legged stool, right: operations, marketing, and finance. IE is all about the first one and has nothing to do with the other two. No worthwhile business degree would omit these, and no worthwhile IE program would include them.

Virgil was the most famous Latin poet, who wrote in the 1st century BC the ‘national’ poem of ancient Rome, Aeneid. A real person, born in Mantua (Northern Italy).
Virgil is for Dante an important reference to the past and a guide, because he represents the literary excellence and a model of wisdom: that's why Dante often calls him maestro. Like Virgil for Latin, Dante is the author of the greatest work of the Italian literature.
Virgil’s soul resides in the limbo, where non baptized good people are. For that reason, he could lead Dante through the Inferno and Purgatory, but not to Heaven.
Virgil (left) and Dante visiting Inferno

Because of a couple of good reasons:
· ‘ch’ does its job well. Unlike in English (chemistry vs chat vs Chicago), it is always pronounced ‘k’, no ambiguity (unless it is at the end of Italian Slavic-sounding family names: for example in Bastianovich, -ch is pronounced as in English)
· such a change would weaken the connection with the past documents and literature
· the implementation of ‘k’ would require investments (e.g. road signs)
· it would add an additional letter to the Italian traditional alphabet, thus complexity
· it is unclear how the given and family names including ‘ch’ would be managed: a family named Bianchi since generations would suddenly be called Bianki?
· ‘ch’ in Italian has a brother (or sister): ‘gh’, which is used with the same rules as ‘ch’ for the sound ‘g’ of ‘god’. Why would you break this nice simmetry?

‘Axis’ defines the alliance between Italy and Germany, born in the late 1930s and soon enlarged to other countries including, in 1940, Japan.
The definition comes from a speech of Mussolini dated November 1936, during which he called the freshly started alliance an ‘Axis’ between Rome and Berlin, around which all other European countries loving peace and collaboration could revolve.
Several expressions used by Mussolini in his speeches became popular, at least in the Italian language, but this one made it internationally. The Axis broke in 1943, during WWII, when Italy surrendered, got invaded by Germany, and eventually declared war on the former allied.
An Axis gadget

I guess you mean ‘why Italy did not join Germany at WWII start’?
The answer is: Italy was not prepared, after a lot of military resources were consumed to conquer Ethiopia and to heavily support Franco in the Spanish Civil War. Hitler knew it, and did not object when Italy did not enter the war in September 1939, albeit the Steel Pact (signed in May 1939 between Italy and Germany) prescribed that the two countries would fight together, both in case of defensive and offensive war. In fact, in the secret part of the Pact it was specified that the war would start not earlier than 1943.
However, Hitler decided to start it earlier. Probably he thought he would not need Italy, and possibly he was concerned about the deterior...

The # symbol in music denotes a sharp. When ascribed to ANY note, this symbol indicates the player to take that particular tone and raise it a half-step upwards.
Below is a key signature with four sharps: We will concentrate just on the treble clef stave, or the top grouping of lines. Where the notes F, C, G, D reside, sharp indicators have been placed.
This simply means that whenever encountering an F, C, G, D, raise them by 1/2 step.
Note: Sometimes the sharps are not written on the key signature, but the symbol will be placed next to the note, as what's referred to as an accidental. Also, every note on the piano, whether black or white keys, is a sharp to the previous halftone tone. A “C” natural is a B#. An “F” natural is an E #. As few as ONE sharp.can occur and as many as 7 as well. Double sharps exist as well.
I hope this helps.

Given: 1.72 m.
Find: Conversion to Feet
Plan: Using a Conversion Factor (CF), convert meters to feet.
CF: 1 m. ≈ 3.2808 ft.
Therefore: 1.72 m. x 3.28 ft./m. ≈ 5.64 ft. ✅
Note: whether for men or women or rocks 1.72 m. is just 1.72 m.
Double Check: Reasonable/Recalculated ✅ ✅
Answer: 5.64 ft. Approximately

Given: Line 4x + 2y = 8
Find: Equation of Perpendicular Line passing through (-1,-1).
Plan:
1. Determine slope of given line
2. Take the Negative Reciprocal slope and the given point to find the perpendicular line equation using the Point-Slope Line Form.
3. Simplify answer into the Slope-Intercept Line Form. y = mx + c
4x + 2y = 8 => 2y = -4x + 8 by subtracting 4x from both sides of the equation.
y = (-4x + 8)/2 => y = -2x + 4 ✅ => Slope m = -2
The negative reciprocal of -2 is -(-1/2) or 1/2 ✅
Then using the Point-Slope Form of a Line substitute using (-1,-1), m = 1/2 and y - y1 = m(x - x1) =>
y - (-1) = 1/2(x -(-1)) => y + 1 = 1/2 x + 1/2 ✅
Now Simplify => y = 1/2 x - 1/2 by subtracting 1 from both sides of the equation. ✅
Double Check: Reasonable/Recalculated ✅ ✅
Answer: The Perpendicular Line: y = 1/2 x - 1/2

Given: Rectangle
Area(A) = 1753 cm^2
Ratio of Lengths x:y = 3:19
Find: x and y
Plan: Use area and the Ratio of Lengths to create a system of Equations to Solve.
Area = 1753 = xy
Ratio of Lengths x/y = 3/19 => x = (3/19)y
Therefore: we will solve the system of equations by substitution.
xy = 1753 = (3/19)y(y) =>
(3y^2)/19 = 1753 Now solve for y.
Multiply both sides by 19
3y^2 = 1753(19)
3y^2 = 33,307 Divide both sides by 3 =>
y^2 = 11,102. 3333…. Or 11,102⅓
Now take the positive square root of both sides of the equation. => y =√(11102.333..) ≈ 105.38 cm. Approximately ✅
Now from above x = (3/19)y = (3/19)(105.38) ≈ 0.1579(105.38) ≈ 16.64 cm. Approximately ✅
Note: 16.64/105.38 ≈ 3/19 => 0.1579 ≈ 0.1579 true
Double Check: Reasonable/ Recalculated ✅ ✅
Approximate Answers:
x ≈ 16.64 cm.
y = 105.38 cm.

Given: Ratio of 2 to 1/3
Find: Value of Ratio
Plan: Use the definition of a ratio.
Ratio of 2 to 1/3 => 2:(1/3) => 2/(1/3)
Now when you divide by a fraction you invert the fraction and multiply. A ratio is a division.
Therefore: 2/(1/3) => 2 x (3/1) = 6 ✅
Double Check: Reasonable/ Simple to Recalculate ✅ ✅
Answer: 6

Given: Pentagon
Angle Ratio 2:3:4:4:5
Find: Largest Angle
Plan: Use the formula for determining the sum of a polygons angle and then a proportional equation which will determine the largest angle.
For a Pentagon with 5 sides, the formula (n - 2)180° will give the sum of the Pentagon’s angles when n = 5.
Substituting (5 - 2)180° = 3(180°) = 540°
Using the given side ratios =>
2x + 3x + 4x + 4x +5x = 540° => 18x = 540° or x = 30°
Therefore: the Interior Angles of the Pentagon are:
60°, 90°, 120°, 120°, 150° and Sum = 540° ✅
Therefore: Largest Angle = 150° ✅
Double Check: Reasonable/Recalculated ✅ ✅
Answer: Largest Angle = 150°

If you know the coordinates of the triangles 3 vertices you can use the Standard Distance Formula which is based on the Pythagorean Theorem.
The use of the Compass, as a mechanical device or instrument, and the 3 vertices does not require that the sides be drawn only that the compass points needs to touch the vertices.
A third possibility is to note that equal sides lie opposite equal angles. Remember, a triangle is equilateral if and only if it is equiangular. Thus, angle measurement can be used. They both belong to the Germanic language family but understanding Danish for Germans would be quite difficult. Danish pronunciation can be quite different from German, as it is characterized by softer consonant sounds and a specific melody. Danish has a more complex vowel system than German, with many more vowel sounds and diphthongs. These differences can make understanding Danish difficult, even if spoken slowly. If a Danish speaker were to speak slowly and clearly, a German speaker might be able to grasp the general meaning of the conversation, especially if they have some basic knowledge of Danish or English.

Hi,
Cardiac = of the heart
Catheter = a narrow tube that is inserted into the circulatory system, in this case it will have a transducer at the tip to measure pressure.
During this procedure, the catheter is inserted into e.g. the femoral artery in the groin to gain access into the left heart [from the heart emerges the aorta, which curves upward, backward and to the left to form the aortic arch then descends anterior to [in front of] the vertebral column [spine] as the descending aorta [called the abdominal aorta lower down] - this branches into the two iliac arteries, which continue as the femoral arteries to supply blood to the legs]. So going backwards, the cardiologist can gain access to the left ventricle and left atrium to measure the pressures and oxygen saturation therein.
Similarly, the right heart chambers are accessed from one of the major veins.
Cardiac catheterization is used less often these days tho it has been around for decades so very safe - the advent of echocardiography has reduced the need for it.
Complications are unusual but can include penetration of a vessel wall or potentially, thrombosis [formation of a clot]; however, appropriate precautions are routinely undertaken, which your cardiologist will go through with you.
Remember THIS IS ONLY GENERAL BASIC INFO - for clinical advice specific to a particular patient, he/she should contact his/her doctor.
Take care!
M

Good afternoon Allen,
Thank you for asking me!
I learnt as a medical student some years ago that the 5 cardinal symptoms/signs of heart disease are:
1. Chest pain
2. Dyspnoea [breathlessness]
3. Dizziness/syncope [fainting]
4. Palpitations [abnormal awareness of the heartbeat]
5. Ankle swelling [due to blood being pooled in the periphery from a failing right ventricle [RVF] leading to back pressure into the systemic veins].
These are some of the symptoms [strictly speaking anything a patient complains of] that often bring to light a heart disease, sometimes in combination, although one needs to be very careful that one does not assume any of these to be necessarily due to a heart problem e.g. occasionally Tietze’s syndrome [costochondritis [inflammation of the rib cartilages]] or pneumothorax or even peptic ulcer, might present with chest pain, as might one of several other conditions
OR:
dyspnoea can be due to asthma or bronchitis or pulmonary embolism.
Equally, other unrelated symptoms, tho less often, might be an indicator of heart disease e.g. a reduced cardiac output might present with confusion or a cognitive impairment, esp in older patients.
A sign is strictly something that is elicited by a clinician during the physical examination, so the patient may not be aware of it e.g. a raised JVP [jugular venous pressure] in RVF or an abnormal murmur heard on auscultation [listening to the heart/lungs with a stethoscope].
You can reduce your chances of a heart issue by eating a healthy diet, living an active life, and making sure you take any medications prescribed for e.g. diabetes mellitus or hypertension.
Best wishes!
M.

Thank you for asking me!
The brief answer is: NOTHING! if, as you say, the cardiologist has determined that your bradycardia is not due to any abnormality, and depending on how low your heart rate actually is.
Conditions that can lead to bradycardia [defined as a heart rate lower than 60 bpm] include
—- hypothyroidism [underactive thyroid gland, a butterfly-shaped structure in the neck anterior to [in front of] your trachea [breathing tube]] - a patient with hypothyroidism might also have slow breathing rate, constipation, feeling cold, etc - a simple blood test can be used to exclude this possibility, which I am sure your doctor already has done.
—- some drugs
—- heart block [you would likely have symptoms e.g. you would suffer sudden episodes of collapsing in complete AV block [called Stokes-Adams attacks]]. An ECG can confirm this if present.
PLEASE FOLLOW THE ADVICE OF YOUR CARDIOLOGIST!
M

Thank you for asking me Kate,
The answer given by Steve seems to be just a blind copy & paste from some internet site. Cadiology in practice does not work like that, I am sorry to say.
The QRS axis on the ECG reflects the direction of the principal vector of the electrical activity in the coronal plane [a flat surface that is vertically oriented and extends from left to right i.e,. facing anteriorly [forward]] that results in depolarization [followed by contraction] of the ventricles. A slight degree of right axis deviation, especially in a patient with no symptoms, does not necessarily indicate any abnormality, and is found in almost all children, and in some adults.
The “normal” QRS axis lies between minus 30 degrees and plus 90 degrees. Zero degrees is defined as directly to the left [looking at the patient [and the ECG axes] from the front, this means to the right, as the clinician faces the patient]. Therefore 90 degrees would be vertically downwards. For more technically-minded readers, the direction from which lead I of the 12-lead ECG “looks at” the heart is zero degrees, and the direction from which lead aVF looks at the heart is 90 degrees, so that the relative net heights of the R waves in these leads [to be precise the anti-sine of these ratios] gives an idea of the actual QRS axis.
I would think that Steve’s answer would produce a lot of anxiety - whether there should be any concern will depend partly on the actual axis in degrees [i.e. how much right axis deviation is present] and as mentioned above, whether there are any symptoms or signs.
One of the causes seen in clinical practice is pulmonary embolism [clot in the lung] [the patient would suffer from sudden chest pain and/or dyspnoea [breathlessness], or worse].
If you are reading this from the automated printout on your ECG, I would take it with a pinch of salt, and would strongly advise you to speak to your GP or cardiologist who ordered the ECG, even if only for reassurance.
Take care!
M.

Good morning Hakan,
Thank you for asking me!
The simple answer to your Q is no, at least in normal adults. [two functions of the spleen are as a reservoir of blood and as an immune organ]. In adults the blood is made in the bone marrow of long bones like the femur.
Having said that, haematopoiesis [production of red blood cells] occurs in the spleen in foetal life, and can resume in adults in certain diseases e.g. thalassaemia [a condition similar to sickle cell anaemia, in both of which the erythrocytes [red blood cells] are abnormal [in sickle cell disease due to the synthesis of abnormal haemoglobin [HbS] due to a genetic defect]].
When red blood cells are produced by the spleen, they are often immature [e.g. proerythroblasts [Greek pro = first as in prototype of a car; eryth = red; the suffix “blasts” refers to immature cells [normal cell names end in “-cytes” [Greek cytos = container i.e. here one that holds the organelles, mitochondria, lysosomes, ER, etc]].
I hope this helps.

Thank you for asking me!
The most common and well-known cardiovascular event is a heart attack [myocardial infarction [M.I.]].
The possible complications of an M.I. depend on the severity of the event, mainly determined by which artery is blocked. Occlusion of a major branch of the coronary arteries, such as the LAD [left anterior descending] is more likely to result in severe complications of some types.
Some complications that can occur are:
1. Cardiac arrhythmia [irregular heart rhythm] - most common cause of death after M.I. - most often detected on an ECG.
2. Acute pericarditis [inflammation of the “coat” of the heart].
3. Cardiac failure - if a large proportion of the myocardium [Greek myo = muscle; cardios = heart so: heart muscle] infarcts [dies due to lack of blood supply], the heart will not be able to beat strongly enough to supply the metabolizing tissues of the body.
4. Left ventricular aneurysm - swelling of the damaged part of the heart muscle - traditionally suspected by a persistently elevated ST segment on the ECG - now better diagnosed with echocardiography. If such an aneurysm ruptures sudden death is possible due to quick exsanguination [loss of blood].
5. Heart block: if part of the conducting system is deprived of blood, A:V [atrioventricular] block or bundle branch block [LBBB [left] or RBBB [right]] can follow.
Other parts of the body can also get involved e.g. the brain if an embolus [moving clot] travels from the left ventricle into the carotid artery and lodges in one of its branches.
A patient who has suffered an M.I. will be looked after by a cardiologist, who will be very well informed about these possibilities, look out for them, and treat as necessary.
M.
