In my opinion, and I am a regular listener to audio books, Alexander Cendese is the finest narrator in the business. I know him best from his reading of Earl Stanley Gardner’s Perry Mason series on Audible. I have every single recording he’s made of these books.
When you listen to a recording by Cendese it is like listening to a full cast production. His delineation between characters is remarkable. It is hard to believe that one person is creating all these voices and that he can be so consistent in differentiating between them. When most narrators voice a person of the opposite sex for example, they they just raise or lower the cadence so the listener is still quite aware that they’re hearing to the same reader. Somehow Cendese makes you believe that you are not only listening to a real woman or girl, but that she is different from every other woman or girl in the story.
I don’t know how he does it; whether he uses some kind of electronic gadget to alter his voice or whether he just happens to be the most talented vocal actor anywhere, but the effect is entirely enjoyable. It is not just his skill at distinguishing the difference in the vocal patterns of women and men. Each of his male characters are distinctly different from each other. Perry Mason is as urbane as Raymond Burr was. Lieutenant Tragg is guttural and brisk. Paul Drake is a bit whiny. All the different supporting characters in each story sound like different people. There is no other narrator I’ve heard who comes even close to what Cendese is able to achieve. I would love to know how he does it.

We are taught not to read for an audience but to one specific person we know will be listening. This creates a sense of intimacy for anyone who listens. Recordings are edited to replace long reading breaths with room noise to create a warm, easy sense of conversation.

Indonesia has misused the area badly, and there is a movement to separate it which, so far, has not had serious support.

To us, the Earth is not moving - our brain instinctively associates that with ‘Everything else moves, not us’.
So, the Sun ‘moves’ across the sky, the stars circulate around the poles… the ground stays still relative to us.
When we do science, we ‘know’ we are rotating/orbiting and the Sun is stationary relative to us, but then the brain forgets the science and says ‘The Sun has risen’ etc.

Go outside - put your hands above your head, as in ‘Reach for the sky’…
That’s it, the sky is everything above you - atmosphere, clouds, sun, stars, moons, planets, space, birds, dust, aeroplanes, satellites, drones, asteroids, comets…
It’s not a ‘real thing’, more a conglomeration of everything ‘up’.

I fear, you fear, he/she fears, we fear, they fear, it fears …
Single nouns use ‘fears’ (apart from I, such are the vagaries of English, and you is a general pointing to ‘someone’ which could be single or group…) , group nouns use ‘fear’ - People is a group noun, so ‘people naturally fear’.
English is totally non-conformative with verbs, so is always hard to guess.

The only instrument in the Brass band that doesn’t use Treble Clef transposing is the Bass trombone. All other Brass Band instruments are built in either Bb or Eb, including the 1st and 2nd Tenor Trombones.
Nowadays the Bass Trombone is a Bb/F instrument with a rotary valve, operated by the left thumb, to switch between the two “sides”. The same instrument is often used by the 1st and 2nd (Tenor ‘bones).
Originally the Bass trombone, as used in British Brass bands, was built in the key of G. It had a handle attached to the slide to be able to reach the lower positions. It looked like this:

However, the orchestral bass Trombone at that time was built in F, so it made sense to have the Brass Band Bass Trombone part written in Concert pitch so it was independent of the instrument being used.
Here’s a video of someone comparing his Grandfather’s G bass Trombone with a modern 2 Trigger instrument:

Medieval covers a wide range of times and places. Still - medieval people were more travelled, often shrewder and more knowledgeable, and their lives more regulated than is commonly shown. Most towns and cities tried to keep rubbish off the streets, keep polluting industries (like tanning and butchery) down stream and maintain order. They were intricate meshes of parish, guild, fraternity, ward and oath-bound association. Early medieval western Europe relied on assemblies of free men to decide a lot (justice, but also changes to local law); medieval nobles were often literate.
I write swords and practical magic - so some way from standard medieval, but I like to avoid simple notions of governance - councils and assemblies are great for showing politicking, arcane legalisms can be fun to write and show another side of life than straight force and I like to mix up the food and clothing (medieval people wore a range of styles and loved bright colours).

Latin was used for court documents, diplomacy, religious services, and formal records. It was the language of teaching in universities, and the common language of scholars and administrators. So it was widely spoken and used, which meant it was a living language, rather different from the classical Latin of Cicero or Caesar. From Renaissance times vernaculars slowly replaced Latin in many fields, and scholars tried to return the language to classical forms. So modern Latin is classical Latin, used in the study of Roman literature and records - unless one is a scholar of medieval records, in which case one learns both classical and the various medieval Latins.

The general answer is that this an effect of vowel reduction in unstressed syllables.
The word library is a good example for this.
We might transcribe it as /ˈlaɪ.brǝˌriː/ with the main stress on the first syllable. The middle syllable is unstressed, and so has a reduced vowel which we generally transcribe as a schwa.
However, the combination /rǝr/ is rather awkward to pronounced rapidly. What tends to happen is one of two things:
(a) the schwa is elided completely - which means that /rǝr/ becomes [ɹː] - so library is pronounced [ˈlaɪ.bɹːi] - effectively reducing the word to two syllables; or
(b) the first /r/ is elided - so library is pronounced [ˈlaɪ.bɜ.ri] - which retains all three syllables.
Something similar has happened to February, although I think the two-syllable version might only be used in North American accents.

The subject of this sentence is she - a third person singular pronoun - so the finite verb must be conjugated in the third person. This could be has (present tense) or had past tense.
The verb to have can be a main verb or an auxiliary verb.
When it’s a main verb, it indicates possession in some way, and it is transitive - meaning it must be followed by an object. The phrase call back might be a noun phrase, but the only meaning I can think of is of is some kind of agreement to call or be called again. In this case it is an countable noun and so it needs an article - so we could say
“She has a call back” - perhaps meaning that someone has called her a second time?
Alternatively, the phrase call back could be a phrasal verb meaning to return a missed call. In this case to have is an auxiliary verb which must be followed by a past participle to indicate the perfect - a completed action - so we could say
“She has called back” - which to me seems more likely.

Charles has written an excellent answer.
I would only like to add that phonemic symbols (such as /ǝ/ ) do not necessarily reflect actual pronunciation. Instead, they describe the phonemes of a word.
For example, let's look at the words late and tail. We transcribe them as /leɪt/ and /teɪl/. That might indicate that the two consonants are pronounced the same in both words. However, they are not. If we transcribe these words phonetically, we have [le͡ɪt] and [tʰe͡ɪɫ].
What’s the differences between [t] and [tʰ] or [l] and [ɫ]? The answer is there is no difference which affects meaning, however they are pronounced differently. We can say that they are allophones - different ways of pronouncing the same phoneme in different contexts.
When it comes to the schwa in English, there is a who range of possible allophones. This is because the schwa is an unstressed vowel, which has been reduced - but the amount of reduction varies from word to word, speaker to speaker and from time to time. Vowels are generally more reduced in functional words than lexical words; more reduced in the middle of an utterance than at the beginning; more reduced in rapid speech than careful speech; more reduced in informal speech than formal speech - and so on.
Let’s take the word depend /dǝˈpend/. This could be pronounced [dɐˈpʰɛnd], [dǝˈpʰɛnd], [dʌˈpʰɛnd], [dɛˈpʰɛnd], [dɪpʰɛnd], [diˈpʰɛnd] or even [ˌdiːˈpʰɛnd] depending on emphasis, intonation speaker, context and so on (let alone accent!).
So we could say that the allophones of /ǝ/ include [ɐ], [ʌ], [ɛ], [ɪ], [i], [iː] as well as [ǝ]. However, thy could also include [æ], [a], [ä], [ɑ], [ɒ] etc when used in other words.
Or we could say that /ǝ/ represents any unstressed reduced vowel. We do often see a reduced e or i transcribed as /ɪ/ rather than /ǝ/. In my opinion this is only partly helpful - it may indicated a frequently heard pronunciation - however it doesn’t show that that it is a reduced vowel.

Up to a point, yes - but only if we take into consideration what a contraction actually is.
There is feature of English where certain functional words are said without any stress at all. This is because we generally only stress the lexical words.
For example if we say “I will buy some fish and chips” the important words are I buy..fish..chips. These are the words which have the stress - in fact if we hear “I buy fish chips” and nothing else, we will probably understand the message pretty accurately, perhaps with a little context to help us.
The functional words will…some…and are unstressed, and in natural speach, they are pronounced in a very reduced way. For instance, the vowels in some and and will be pronounced as a schwa /ǝ/ or even be completely missing. The I will /aɪ wɪl/ transforms into /aɪ‿l/ losing the /w/ glide. And of course in writing we spell this I’ll -as a contraction.
So - we can write I will buy some fish and chips as I’ll buy some fish and chips.
But can we always replace I will with I’ll?
The answer is no. This only works where the will is unstressed.
If “Yes, I will” (in answer to a request, perhaps) then the most important words are Yes … will. The I is less important as it will be obvious from the context. In this case the contraction is not possible.

This is a question about the phonemic analysis of North American English.
As you have identified, a key difference between British and North American pronunciation is rhoticity. A non-rhotic accent is one where a written r is not pronounced as a consonant unless it is followed by a vowel.
Except that it it is rather more complicated than that.
RP phonemic transcriptions omit the /r/ completely - e.g. part /pɑːt/ - unless it is at the end of a word, when it is added in brackets - e.g. far /fɑː(r)/ - which indicates that it is pronounced when the following word starts with a vowel.
However, even when not pronounced, the written r does have an effect on the pronunciation of the vowel before it:
ar usually indicates /ɑː/
er, ir and ur usually indicate /ɜː/
or usually indicates /ɔː/
although in unstressed syllables, it will be reduced to a schwa /ǝ/.
However, not all British accents are non-rhotic. In the Bristol accent, for example, these are pronounced /ɑːr/, /ɜːr/, /ɔːr/ and /ǝr/ respectively - with a retroflex /r/ - [ɹ].
So is this how it works in North American rhotic accents too? Not really.
There is no phonemic vowel length, so ar indicates /ɑr/ and or indicates /ɔr/.
However, an interesting thing happens with er, ir and ur. The /ɜ/ vowel has actually has a very similar mouth shape the the retroflex [ɹ] so, what tends to happen in many speakers is a coalescence of the vowel and the approximant [ɜ͡ɹ]. This is the so-called R-colored vowel, which in phonemic transcriptions is often represented as /ɝ/ or /ɚ/ - but some phonemic transcription show this as /ɜr/ or /ǝr/.
But the degree to which this vowel is pronounced coalesced as [ɜ͡ɹ] or [ɜɹ] as two sequential phones does seem to vary from accent to accent, from speaker to speaker and from also time to time.

This does not happen across all British accents - but in a minority of regional and social accents around London - which includes Cockney/Estuary English, MLE] and South London.
What you are hearing is a merger of /θ/ and /f/ to [f].
This gives rise to Fort Neef as the humorous local name for Thornton Heath in South London.
There is a similar merger of /ð/ and /v/ to [v] in words such as mother, brother etc. but this does not occur at the beginning of words, such as this, that etc. which (except in MLE) are pronounced with [ð]. In MLE, the /ð/ at the beginning of a word is more usually pronounced [d].

If you are doing a vaginal ultrasound you would expect to be able to see a heartbeat at six weeks even if the uterus is retroverted. But dates can be off and if I did not find a heartbeat at six weeks I would check HCG levels two days apart to see if they are rising appropriately and repeat the ultrasound in one to two weeks.

The ultimate method of differentiating between period and pregnancy is a positive pregnancy test. No period is also a big sign. The dating of a pregnancy starts at the time of the period before conception. So a one week pregnancy is technically not yet pregnant. The first week after conception does not usually have any symptoms as the blastocyst is in the process of implanting and just starting to produce HCG.

The first Ob appointment is scheduled between 6–8 weeks in a perfect world. Most appointments in early pregnancy are every four weeks for an uncomplicated pregnancy. At 28–32 weeks they become every two weeks and at 36 weeks become weekly. Trying to go longer than this schedule risks complications and the escalation of mild problems into serious ones.

It could be completely normal. It can take a few years to become regular. If you are a normal weight with a normal activity level it may take a while for your next period without anything being abnormal. If you are very overweight or underweight you might want to see a gynecologist for evaluation. If you are sexually active you need some type of contraception even without having regular periods. Talk to a parent about your concerns. For most girls it is easier to talk to their mother.

AZI is formulated to treat symptoms of a bladder infection without treating the cause. Even the formula to prevent infection does not treat infection. Talk to your doctor about your symptoms. Bladder infection in pregnancy has a higher risk of becoming a kidney infection. All medications, even over the counter, should be discussed with with your doctor.

Some pregnant people have vaginal bleeding that they might think is a period but it’s not. A period is the sloughing of the uterine lining. Bleeding during pregnancy usually arises from the margin of the placenta and a can be a sign of impending miscarriage or premature labor or separation of placenta and uterine wall. Bleeding during known pregnancy should always prompt a call to your Ob provider so evaluation can be done.

It’s difficult to tell what your singing sounds like when you’re busy singing.
Record yourself. Your computer, pad, or phone has an app that records. This will give you a better idea of what you sound like. It’ll also show you what needs fixing, if something does.
Don’t just do this once. Nobody likes the sound of their own voice on the first playback. Do it a number of times over a period of days. I’m betting that you’ll find that you’ll hear better, and that you’ll like what you hear better.

My answer to the submitted question:
ADHD and Dyslexia are moderately related. Between 25 and 40% of those who have one, also have the other. Even though they do have some degree of comorbidity, the two are based on entirely different brain systems.
Dyslexia, as shown by the 20-year longitudinal study at Yale by Shaywitz, is connected with brain dysfunction in the angular gyrus. The angular gyrus is responsible for phonetic decoding, which is how we teach reading. These children are not reading because we are not teaching the right way.
It is easy to identify this type of dyslexia. Show the person a group of words. Point to words and ask them to say it. Compare that to, say the word and ask them to point to it. The dyslexics will not be able to say the word, but can point to it. They know what the word means, even if they cannot say it. According to the statistics, you can expect 25 to 40% to be ADHD

My answer to the submitted question:
Ken Saladin explained the mechanism of cell membranes that lead to an action potential. I start with the action potential. Every neuron emits between 5 and 200 action potentials per second. When these action potentials stop, we are brain-dead.
As an example, Neuron A vibrates (action potentials per second) at 10 Hz. Stimulation from another neuron may change rate to 12 Hz. Neuron A has a synapse with Neuron B. Will the change in rate from A “cross the synapse” and change the rate in B? A may be connected to 5000 neurons in addition to B, which is also interconnected. Information is a result of the “vibrational” pattern of neurons.
Electrical activity within the neuron results in action potentials. Information arises from changes and patterns in action potentials. There is no flow from neuron to neuron.

My answer to the submitted question:
You may be talking about something beyond ADD, but a broader preference for moving while working. Students who reported they preferred moving (Based on the Dunn and Dunn Learning Styles profile) when they worked were compared to those who preferred sitting. There were two tasks. Learn a group of words while sitting at a desk. Learn the words that were placed on different work stations. The students who said they liked to move did better on the workstation than desk, and vice versa. This was a published, prize winning, Ph.D. dissertation where I did the analysis.
Maybe it is the ADD, or maybe it is just who you are, but you prefer physically moving. If that is the way you work, take advantage of it.

0 is the only rational number that terminates that you cant write down in this sort of way. For example 1 - as you mentioned can be written, .999… and 5/8 can be written as .625 or .624999… this means if a number terminates, we can find a alternative representation of that number.

You dont need Trig really.
Goog algebra is essential. But I think to get a handle on what Calculus is - rather than just to memorise the formulas and calculate you need a little bit of analytic geometry.
This is just knowing what a function is, how to graph it, and if it is a straight line how to calculate its slope, and some sort of intuition of what that means. In essence calculus is an extension of this idea of slope to curves. (simplfying a touch).
Also, and it might be taught in most calculus books anyhow, is to try to understand what a limit is. You might think limits are part of culculus anyway, but in some courses they may be introduced in a pre Calculus. Dont miss them.

“Do electronics that are used in space last longer than terrestrial devices?” is a difficult question to answer.
My experience with terrestrial devices has varied from the device not working when new to working properly for decades.
Space is a difficult environment and electronic components for devices sent into space are generally manufactured and tested to different specifications.
My observation is electronics used in space will last about the same length of time as consumer electronics last on earth. Satellites can orbit and function for decades.

“If computers were invented in 1945, why didn't people have any computers until much later?” The simple answer is “people” didn’t have any computers until the personal computer appeared in the middle to late 1970’s. Early computers filled rooms, were extremely expensive, and were run by technicians. The US space program resulted in transistors and eventually integrated circuits which enabled manufacturers to reduce the size and power consumption of functional computers to the point they were able to be used in a house or regular small business.

This question is defective. “… the numbers 15a 16b and 16a-15b are both …” both refers to two values, but there are three values listed:
15a;
16b; and,
16a-15b.
If 15a times 16b was intended, it should look like “15a * 16b” or “15a X 16b”, otherwise they are separate values. “both” implies 2 items, no more, no less. Likewise, if 15a + 16b or 15a - 16b, was intended, the sign is missing.
Fix the question, and we may think about answering it. By the way, with spreadsheet technology, the question can be solved by perfect induction.

A charger is an adapter that is used for charging.
Some devices have many names. Another name for an adapter is power cube. The device typically connects to the electrical grid, but some plug into the 12V system of a vehicle. The device accepts input voltage and current or more commonly a range of input voltages and currents and provides an output voltage and current, although some also provide a range of output voltages and currents. The output voltage and current may be used to power a device, to charge a battery, or to simultaneously do both.

Asked: “Does putting your phone in airplane mode save battery power while it is charging at night while you are sleeping?”
Yes. It does save power, but it is pointless.
Airplane mode turns off services that use transmitters, which disconnects the phone from cellular services and Wi-Fi. Which prevents contact with other people you may need to communicate with.
Since nearly all cell phones can recharge in an hour or two while all the necessary services are running, there is no point in setting airplane mode before attaching the charger for 6 or more hours.

A sphere when viewed from any angle will look like a circle. The Moon and Earth are both spherical. The Moon stays in orbit around Earth because it has angular momentum. Because space is a vacuum, there is no air friction to slow it down, so it stays where it is. It’s orbit is not a perfect circle, so sometimes it’s a little closer, sometimes a little farther.
E=Mc2 expresses energy/mass equivalency and has nothing directly to do with gravity. To understand the basics of gravity, look at the simple equations of Newton. They are much easier to understand than Einstein’s equations for General Relativity and work very well when dealing with normal conditions of low velocities and masses. One exception is our GPS system. It produces such accurate position readings only because it corrects for the effects of relativity.

Firstly, one immediate implication of your question is that you don’t know the difference between rotating and revolving. That aside, I suppose the most salient implication is that Newton’s equations predicting elliptical orbits for revolving bodies is valid. Maybe you’ve heard of Isaac Newton? The thing is, a circle is just a special kind of ellipse that has zero eccentricity. This will never be found in nature because there is always some degree of variance from a perfect circle.

Not at all because the Sun’s core is a nuclear “fire”, not a chemical one. This amount of water would nearly double the Sun’s mass and add to the core’s pressure, thus increasing the Sun’s luminosity by about 10 times, destroying life on Earth. Btw, 16/18ths of the mass of water is oxygen, so this would create an unusually oxygenated main sequence star with unusual consequences as regards the fusion processes in the core. It would take an astrophysicist to tell us what would happen once the dust settled, but my guess is that none of it would make the Sun dimmer, only brighter.

There are credible accounts in support of reincarnation. I suppose that would qualify as evidence of life in other dimensions. It is possible that new instruments such as the JWST may be able to identify oxygen in exoplanetary atmospheres. That would be a good indicator for life, but it would not be a certainty. Certainties are in the realm of mathematics, not science. Science predicts, e.g., that the Sun will rise in the east tomorrow, but it cannot provide absolute certainty of this.

PORTLAND, Maine (AP) — Depending on whom you ask, Maine’s proposed “right to food” constitutional amendment would simply put people in charge of how and what they eat — or would endanger animals and food supplies, and turn urban neighborhoods into cattle pastures.
For supporters, the language is short and to the point, ensuring the right to grow vegetables and raise livestock in an era when corporatization threatens local ownership of the food supply, a constitutional experiment that has never been tried in any state.
For opponents and skeptics, it’s deceptively vague, representing a threat to food safety and animal welfare, and could embolden residents to raise cows in their backyards in cities like Portland and Bangor.
In the Nov. 2 election, voters will be asked if they favor an amendment to the Maine Constitution “to declare that all individuals have a natural, inherent and unalienable right to grow, raise, harvest, produce and consume the food of their own choosing for their own nourishment, sustenance, bodily health and well-being.”

Nordic citizens in Nordic countries are considered Nordic not foreigners. So a swede in Finland would be Nordic neighbour, not a foreigner.
In official statistics citizens of other Nordic countries are listed as Nordics, citizenens of EU countries as EU and then there are others listed as 3rd coubtry citizens.

It doesn’t. Finnish is very strait forward with pronouciation. There are only couple of exceptions and “uo” is not one of them. For example “Suomi” (Finland / Finnish language in Finnish) is straitforward “Suo-mi”, just like in all other words. “ue” is very different like in “lue” (to read, imperative).
Most letter are prononced the same as Spanish (and most European languages). The main differences to Spanish are that Finnish h is Spanish j, Finnish j is Spanish y, Finnish y is sound of it’s own kind a lije y in English “sympathy”, Spanish ll is Finish j, Finnish ä is like a in English “and”, Finnish ö is like French e in article “le” and Finish å is actually Swedish o.

Someone without gender. Someone who doesn’t associate with the concept of gender, without that extending to the existence of such a concept in the first place.
Just as someone amoral isn’t someone who disbelieves in the existence of morality, but rather doesn’t personally believe/enact it themselves. Just as someone who is asexual to varying degrees doesn’t feel sexual attraction, without getting into the existence of such attraction for someone else. Just as an atheist is someone with an absence of belief in the existence of supramundane entities known as gods without trying to challenge the existence of belief in such things.
What you’re trying to compare this to is -isms, and I suspect atheism in particular, but while agenderism might present itself as a movement challenging the binary understanding of gender that genderism presents (though, to my knowledge, agenderism isn’t actually the word for such a movement), being agender is something else entirely. It’s a personal signifier, in this case describing someone not identifying with gender, and thereby often (not always) presenting as genderless or gender neutral.

The fluidity has more to do with the process than the result, so to say, and more about feelings than necessarily presentation.
Yes, a gender fluid person will in sum have masculine and feminine traits (or at least feel they do. Gender identity and presentation often, but not always, overlap). But the fluidity highlights that this fluctuates. Sometimes they feel quite feminine, other times quite masculine, sometimes both or even neither.

I’d say it’s more about presentation than necessarily what you say when it comes to flirting, but if I had to judge them on «neutral» ground I’d probably rank har higher on the flirtation scale (though all that said, flirting with women as a woman is fraught with platonic misunderstandings).

I can give you a word-for-word translation, but it might bot help your confusion…
 * Går - goes (as in, “how goes it”, or “how is it going”, a bit on the archaic side for English, but in common use in Norwegian. Beyond being a word for walking, it’s about something moving along, a continuous state of something. Norwegian does not usually use the verb “to be” for this like English does).
 * Det - it (here used as a formal subject, because “you” is treated as an object in the sentence).
 * Bra - well/good (can be both an adverb and an adjective. Currently an adjective, hence the formal subject mentioned above. “Goes it well” might sound rather old-fashioned in English, but is perfectly valid in Norwegian).
 * Med - with (a preposition, indicating the start of a prepositional phrase. You’re specifying whose wellbeing you’re inquiring about. Because it’s a prepositional phrase, and because the formal subject is already in the above, “med deg” is actually voluntary. Context will often clarify if it’s you, someone, or something else you’re concerned about).
 * Deg - you (more specifically the object rather than subject form of “you”. These are distinguished in Norwegian, where the subject form is “du”. In nynorsk the subject and object forms can also be dissimilar when plural, though a combined version exists).

“Går det bra” is a rather standard phrase similar to “how goes it” in English, though as you can see from the translation the Norwegian phrase specifically asks if it’s going well, rather than that being the generally implied meaning of the English alternative. I’d also add that unlike English, the Norwegian phrase is less of a day-to-day nicety (in fact, if you ask too frequently it might be interpreted as the person you’re asking looking unwell, or doing poorly, since you’re asking for constant reassurance that’s not the case).
Norwegian, much like English, is a SVO language. The general structure is Subject-verb-object. When a statement is turned into a question (without using a question word), we also often change postions between the verb and the subject. For instance:
 * You are here (subject-verb- well… it’s an adverb - but it’s the subject-cerb placement that’s important anyway)
 * Are you here? (Changing position between the verb and the subject).

Similarly the question “går det bra?” is changed to “det går bra”...

Medieval economies were based on agriculture, not on industry or capital in the modern sense. Thus, the key to wealth and power was based on military might and land ownership. Medieval monarchs and their nobility were predominately warriors and landowners and their power was real enough. They were some puppet kings, but they were usually puppets of powerful nobles, not of bankers. (For instance, most of the later Merovingian kings were puppets of different factions of Frankish nobles, who would eventually displace them.)
Bankers and moneylenders existed, as did merchants, but they were generally sneered at by the upper class as greedy and unnatural upstarts. This disdain could also be found throughout Asia; their economies as well were based on agriculture and power and wealth also came from land ownership. In most all places except China and Korea, this also meant political dominance by a warrior-landowner class; China and Korea instead had a scholar-bureaucrat class instead, but in practice, that still meant that trade was looked at something base and dishonorable.
There were a few merchant families who managed to join the upper class, but they generally did so by using their newfound wealth to purchase land and estates. Not sure if you've ever read a Jane Austen novel, but they demonstrate amply that disdain for banking and trade was still found among the upper class as late as the 19th century.
The only places where merchants and bankers ranked at the top were the so-called merchant republics, such as many of the northern Italy city-states (think Venice and Florence) and the Novgorod Republic. These, however, were rare exceptions.

Moneylenders have existed from ancient times through Asia, Africa, and Europe. They were not large banks in the modern sense, however, because economies from ancient times to up until about the dawn of the 19th century were very different from any modern economy.
The idea of them controlling political power is pretty much pure fantasy, however. Moneylenders were usually denounced as immoral parasites in most religions and philosophies, had difficulty getting back even half of the money they loaned (because most of it was to elites who had enough political power to get away with not paying back their debts), and frequently went bankrupt.
Moneylenders who managed to collect even somewhat sizable fortunes most often tried to use their newfound wealth to buy land, because land was a much safer investment than moneylending or being a merchant.

No.
Numerous monastic chronicles from the reigns of the Norman kings exist, such as those by Guillaume of Jumièges, Guillaume of Poitiers, Orderic Vitalis, and Guillaume of Malmsbury. All of these men were clergy and held firm to the Catholic Church's stance of appropriate conduct.
They have say a lot about William the Conqueror, William Rufus, Robert Curthose, Henry I, Stephen and Empress Maude and not all of it is flattering or approving. Yet, they have absolutely nothing to say about the Norman noblemen having the right to take the virginity of Anglo-Saxon brides.
They mention William I ordering the Harrying of the North and are critical of their lax sexual mores of Robert, William Rufus, and Henry I, so it beggars belief of why they'd ignore widespread use of the Right of the First Night, if it actually existed.
Anyone who actually tried to institute something like the Right of the First Night in the Middle Ages would have immediately found themselves on the receiving end of a massive peasant revolt and the clergy probably would have sided with them.
Bigamy and incest were both grounds for excommunication and adultery was considered a mortal sin, but we're supposed to believe that Catholic clergy would just quietly accept the Right of the First Night? That's very hard to believe.
Certainly, some lords, whether Norman or otherwise, did take advantage of their wealthy and privileges to extort sex from their vassals and serfs, but that weren't legally entitled to do that, anymore than a modern boss is legally entitled to demand sexual favors for employment.

You seem to be vastly overestimating how much of the House of Wessex was left.
By 1066, the House of Wessex had been reduced to exactly three people: Cristina, Margaret, and Edgar Ætheling. Cristina and Margaret were both female while Edgar, despite being the last male member of the House of Wessex, never seems to have garnered much in the way of political support amongst the English.
Edgar did launch some campaigns with Scottish assistance to regain the throne, but they were abortive. Instead, most of the threats against William's rule came from his earls and his own family, not from Edgar Ætheling.
